args.name: bgcolor
args.docString: Sets the background color of the hover labels for this trace

args.name: bordercolor
args.docString: Sets the border color of the hover labels for this trace.

args.name: font
args.docString: Sets the font used in hover labels.

args.name: align
args.docString: Sets the horizontal alignment of the text content within hover label box. Has an effect only if the hover label text spans more two or more lines

args.name: namelength
args.docString: Sets the default length (in number of characters) of the trace name in the hover labels for all traces. -1 shows the whole name regardless of length. 0-3 shows the first 0-3 characters, and an integer >3 will show the whole name if it is less than that many characters, but if it is longer, will truncate to `namelength - 3` characters and add an ellipsis.

args.name: bgcolorsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  bgcolor .

args.name: bordercolorsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  bordercolor .

args.name: alignsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  align .

args.name: namelengthsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  namelength .

args.name: token
args.docString: The stream id number links a data trace on a plot with a stream. See https://chart-studio.plotly.com/settings for more details.

args.name: maxpoints
args.docString: Sets the maximum number of points to keep on the plots from an incoming stream. If `maxpoints` is set to *50*, only the newest 50 points will be displayed on the plot.

token.name: string
token.docString: The stream id number links a data trace on a plot with a stream. See https://chart-studio.plotly.com/settings for more details.

maxpoints.name: number
maxpoints.docString: Sets the maximum number of points to keep on the plots from an incoming stream. If `maxpoints` is set to *50*, only the newest 50 points will be displayed on the plot.

returns.name: Transform
returns.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets the line color.

args.name: width
args.docString: Sets the line width (in px).

args.name: shape
args.docString: Determines the line shape. With *spline* the lines are drawn using spline interpolation. The other available values correspond to step-wise line shapes.

args.name: smoothing
args.docString: Has an effect only if `shape` is set to *spline* Sets the amount of smoothing. *0* corresponds to no smoothing (equivalent to a *linear* shape).

args.name: dash
args.docString: Sets the dash style of lines. Set to a dash type string (*solid*, *dot*, *dash*, *longdash*, *dashdot*, or *longdashdot*) or a dash length list in px (eg *5px,10px,2px,2px*).

args.name: simplify
args.docString: Simplifies lines by removing nearly-collinear points. When transitioning lines, it may be desirable to disable this so that the number of points along the resulting SVG path is unaffected.

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets the line color.

width.name: number
width.docString: Sets the line width (in px).

shape.name: enumerated
shape.docString: Determines the line shape. With *spline* the lines are drawn using spline interpolation. The other available values correspond to step-wise line shapes.

smoothing.name: number
smoothing.docString: Has an effect only if `shape` is set to *spline* Sets the amount of smoothing. *0* corresponds to no smoothing (equivalent to a *linear* shape).

dash.name: string
dash.docString: Sets the dash style of lines. Set to a dash type string (*solid*, *dot*, *dash*, *longdash*, *dashdot*, or *longdashdot*) or a dash length list in px (eg *5px,10px,2px,2px*).

simplify.name: boolean
simplify.docString: Simplifies lines by removing nearly-collinear points. When transitioning lines, it may be desirable to disable this so that the number of points along the resulting SVG path is unaffected.

args.name: symbol
args.docString: Sets the marker symbol type. Adding 100 is equivalent to appending *-open* to a symbol name. Adding 200 is equivalent to appending *-dot* to a symbol name. Adding 300 is equivalent to appending *-open-dot* or *dot-open* to a symbol name.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the marker opacity.

args.name: size
args.docString: Sets the marker size (in px).

args.name: maxdisplayed
args.docString: Sets a maximum number of points to be drawn on the graph. *0* corresponds to no limit.

args.name: sizeref
args.docString: Has an effect only if `marker.size` is set to a numerical array. Sets the scale factor used to determine the rendered size of marker points. Use with `sizemin` and `sizemode`.

args.name: sizemin
args.docString: Has an effect only if `marker.size` is set to a numerical array. Sets the minimum size (in px) of the rendered marker points.

args.name: sizemode
args.docString: Has an effect only if `marker.size` is set to a numerical array. Sets the rule for which the data in `size` is converted to pixels.

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets themarkercolor. It accepts either a specific color or an array of numbers that are mapped to the colorscale relative to the max and min values of the array or relative to `marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax` if set.

args.name: cauto
args.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here in `marker.color`) or the bounds set in `marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax`  Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. Defaults to `false` when `marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax` are set by the user.

args.name: cmin
args.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.color` and if set, `marker.cmax` must be set as well.

args.name: cmax
args.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.color` and if set, `marker.cmin` must be set as well.

args.name: cmid
args.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `marker.cmin` and/or `marker.cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.color`. Has no effect when `marker.cauto` is `false`.

args.name: colorscale
args.docString: Sets the colorscale. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

args.name: autocolorscale
args.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `marker.colorscale`. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

args.name: reversescale
args.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. If true, `marker.cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `marker.cmax` will correspond to the first color.

args.name: showscale
args.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array.

args.name: coloraxis
args.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

args.name: family
args.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  family .

args.name: sizesrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  size .

args.name: colorsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  color .

returns.name: Textfont

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this set of error bars is visible.

args.name: type
args.docString: Determines the rule used to generate the error bars. If *constant`, the bar lengths are of a constant value. Set this constant in `value`. If *percent*, the bar lengths correspond to a percentage of underlying data. Set this percentage in `value`. If *sqrt*, the bar lengths correspond to the square of the underlying data. If *data*, the bar lengths are set with data set `array`.

args.name: symmetric
args.docString: Determines whether or not the error bars have the same length in both direction (top/bottom for vertical bars, left/right for horizontal bars.

args.name: array
args.docString: Sets the data corresponding the length of each error bar. Values are plotted relative to the underlying data.

args.name: arrayminus
args.docString: Sets the data corresponding the length of each error bar in the bottom (left) direction for vertical (horizontal) bars Values are plotted relative to the underlying data.

args.name: value
args.docString: Sets the value of either the percentage (if `type` is set to *percent*) or the constant (if `type` is set to *constant*) corresponding to the lengths of the error bars.

args.name: valueminus
args.docString: Sets the value of either the percentage (if `type` is set to *percent*) or the constant (if `type` is set to *constant*) corresponding to the lengths of the error bars in the bottom (left) direction for vertical (horizontal) bars

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets the stoke color of the error bars.

args.name: thickness
args.docString: Sets the thickness (in px) of the error bars.

args.name: width
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the cross-bar at both ends of the error bars.

args.name: arraysrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  array .

args.name: arrayminussrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  arrayminus .

At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

args.name: autocolorscale
args.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `marker.line.colorscale`. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

args.name: reversescale
args.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. If true, `marker.line.cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `marker.line.cmax` will correspond to the first color.

args.name: coloraxis
args.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

args.name: widthsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  width .

args.name: colorsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  color .

width.name: number
width.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the lines bounding the marker points.

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets themarker.linecolor. It accepts either a specific color or an array of numbers that are mapped to the colorscale relative to the max and min values of the array or relative to `marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax` if set.

cauto.name: boolean
cauto.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here in `marker.line.color`) or the bounds set in `marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax`  Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. Defaults to `false` when `marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax` are set by the user.

cmin.name: number
cmin.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.line.color` and if set, `marker.line.cmax` must be set as well.

cmax.name: number
cmax.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.line.color` and if set, `marker.line.cmin` must be set as well.

cmid.name: number
cmid.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `marker.line.cmin` and/or `marker.line.cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.line.color`. Has no effect when `marker.line.cauto` is `false`.

colorscale.name: colorscale
colorscale.docString: Sets the colorscale. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

autocolorscale.name: boolean
autocolorscale.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `marker.line.colorscale`. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

reversescale.name: boolean
reversescale.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. If true, `marker.line.cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `marker.line.cmax` will correspond to the first color.

coloraxis.name: subplotid
coloraxis.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

args.name: thicknessmode
args.docString: Determines whether this color bar's thickness (i.e. the measure in the constant color direction) is set in units of plot *fraction* or in *pixels*. Use `thickness` to set the value.

args.name: thickness
args.docString: Sets the thickness of the color bar This measure excludes the size of the padding, ticks and labels.

args.name: lenmode
args.docString: Determines whether this color bar's length (i.e. the measure in the color variation direction) is set in units of plot *fraction* or in *pixels. Use `len` to set the value.

args.name: len
args.docString: Sets the length of the color bar This measure excludes the padding of both ends. That is, the color bar length is this length minus the padding on both ends.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x position of the color bar (in plot fraction).

args.name: xanchor
args.docString: Sets this color bar's horizontal position anchor. This anchor binds the `x` position to the *left*, *center* or *right* of the color bar.

args.name: xpad
args.docString: Sets the amount of padding (in px) along the x direction.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y position of the color bar (in plot fraction).

args.name: yanchor
args.docString: Sets this color bar's vertical position anchor This anchor binds the `y` position to the *top*, *middle* or *bottom* of the color bar.

args.name: ypad
args.docString: Sets the amount of padding (in px) along the y direction.

args.name: outlinecolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: outlinewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

args.name: bordercolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: borderwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) or the border enclosing this color bar.

args.name: bgcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of padded area.

args.name: tickmode
args.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

args.name: nticks
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

args.name: tick0
args.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: dtick
args.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

args.name: tickvals
args.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

args.name: ticktext
args.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

args.name: ticks
args.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

args.name: ticklabelposition
args.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn.

args.name: ticklen
args.docString: Sets the tick length (in px).

args.name: tickwidth
args.docString: Sets the tick width (in px).

args.name: tickcolor
args.docString: Sets the tick color.

args.name: showticklabels
args.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

args.name: tickfont
args.docString: Sets the color bar's tick label font

args.name: tickangle
args.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

args.name: tickformat
args.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: tickprefix
args.docString: Sets a tick label prefix.

args.name: showtickprefix
args.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

args.name: ticksuffix
args.docString: Sets a tick label suffix.

args.name: showticksuffix
args.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

args.name: separatethousands
args.docString: If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated

args.name: exponentformat
args.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

args.name: minexponent
args.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

args.name: showexponent
args.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

args.name: tickvalssrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

args.name: ticktextsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

args.name: family
args.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.name: Tickfont

args.name: enabled
args.docString: Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`.

args.name: dtickrange
args.docString: range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null*

args.name: value
args.docString: string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat*

args.name: name
args.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

args.name: templateitemname
args.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

args.docString: Sets the text font color of selected points.

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets the text font color of selected points.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the marker opacity of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists.

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets the marker color of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists.

args.name: size
args.docString: Sets the marker size of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists.

opacity.name: number
opacity.docString: Sets the marker opacity of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists.

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets the marker color of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists.

size.name: number
size.docString: Sets the marker size of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists.

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets the text font color of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists.

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets the text font color of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists.

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: selectedpoints
args.docString: Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x coordinates.

args.name: x0
args.docString: Alternate to `x`. Builds a linear space of x coordinates. Use with `dx` where `x0` is the starting coordinate and `dx` the step.

args.name: dx
args.docString: Sets the x coordinate step. See `x0` for more info.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y coordinates.

args.name: y0
args.docString: Alternate to `y`. Builds a linear space of y coordinates. Use with `dy` where `y0` is the starting coordinate and `dy` the step.

args.name: dy
args.docString: Sets the y coordinate step. See `y0` for more info.

args.name: xperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the x axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: yperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the y axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: xperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the x0 axis. When `x0period` is round number of weeks, the `x0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: yperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the y0 axis. When `y0period` is round number of weeks, the `y0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: xperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the x axis.

args.name: yperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the y axis.

args.name: stackgroup
args.docString: Set several scatter traces (on the same subplot) to the same stackgroup in order to add their y values (or their x values if `orientation` is *h*). If blank or omitted this trace will not be stacked. Stacking also turns `fill` on by default, using *tonexty* (*tonextx*) if `orientation` is *h* (*v*) and sets the default `mode` to *lines* irrespective of point count. You can only stack on a numeric (linear or log) axis. Traces in a `stackgroup` will only fill to (or be filled to) other traces in the same group. With multiple `stackgroup`s or some traces stacked and some not, if fill-linked traces are not already consecutive, the later ones will be pushed down in the drawing order.

args.name: orientation
args.docString: Only relevant when `stackgroup` is used, and only the first `orientation` found in the `stackgroup` will be used - including if `visible` is *legendonly* but not if it is `false`. Sets the stacking direction. With *v* (*h*), the y (x) values of subsequent traces are added. Also affects the default value of `fill`.

args.name: groupnorm
args.docString: Only relevant when `stackgroup` is used, and only the first `groupnorm` found in the `stackgroup` will be used - including if `visible` is *legendonly* but not if it is `false`. Sets the normalization for the sum of this `stackgroup`. With *fraction*, the value of each trace at each location is divided by the sum of all trace values at that location. *percent* is the same but multiplied by 100 to show percentages. If there are multiple subplots, or multiple `stackgroup`s on one subplot, each will be normalized within its own set.

args.name: stackgaps
args.docString: Only relevant when `stackgroup` is used, and only the first `stackgaps` found in the `stackgroup` will be used - including if `visible` is *legendonly* but not if it is `false`. Determines how we handle locations at which other traces in this group have data but this one does not. With *infer zero* we insert a zero at these locations. With *interpolate* we linearly interpolate between existing values, and extrapolate a constant beyond the existing values.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets text elements associated with each (x,y) pair. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (x,y) coordinates. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: texttemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information text that appear on points. Note that this will override `textinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. Every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Sets hover text elements associated with each (x,y) pair. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (x,y) coordinates. To be seen, trace `hoverinfo` must contain a *text* flag.

args.name: mode
args.docString: Determines the drawing mode for this scatter trace. If the provided `mode` includes *text* then the `text` elements appear at the coordinates. Otherwise, the `text` elements appear on hover. If there are less than 20 points and the trace is not stacked then the default is *lines+markers*. Otherwise, *lines*.

args.name: hoveron
args.docString: Do the hover effects highlight individual points (markers or line points) or do they highlight filled regions? If the fill is *toself* or *tonext* and there are no markers or text, then the default is *fills*, otherwise it is *points*.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: connectgaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the provided data arrays are connected.

args.name: cliponaxis
args.docString: Determines whether or not markers and text nodes are clipped about the subplot axes. To show markers and text nodes above axis lines and tick labels, make sure to set `xaxis.layer` and `yaxis.layer` to *below traces*.

args.name: fill
args.docString: Sets the area to fill with a solid color. Defaults to *none* unless this trace is stacked, then it gets *tonexty* (*tonextx*) if `orientation` is *v* (*h*) Use with `fillcolor` if not *none*. *tozerox* and *tozeroy* fill to x=0 and y=0 respectively. *tonextx* and *tonexty* fill between the endpoints of this trace and the endpoints of the trace before it, connecting those endpoints with straight lines (to make a stacked area graph); if there is no trace before it, they behave like *tozerox* and *tozeroy*. *toself* connects the endpoints of the trace (or each segment of the trace if it has gaps) into a closed shape. *tonext* fills the space between two traces if one completely encloses the other (eg consecutive contour lines), and behaves like *toself* if there is no trace before it. *tonext* should not be used if one trace does not enclose the other. Traces in a `stackgroup` will only fill to (or be filled to) other traces in the same group. With multiple `stackgroup`s or some traces stacked and some not, if fill-linked traces are not already consecutive, the later ones will be pushed down in the drawing order.

args.name: fillcolor
args.docString: Sets the fill color. Defaults to a half-transparent variant of the line color, marker color, or marker line color, whichever is available.

args.name: textposition
args.docString: Sets the positions of the `text` elements with respects to the (x,y) coordinates.

args.name: textfont
args.docString: Sets the text font.

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: xaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: yaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: idssrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ids .

args.name: customdatasrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  customdata .

args.name: metasrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  meta .

args.name: hoverinfosrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hoverinfo .

args.name: xsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  x .

args.name: ysrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  y .

args.name: textsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  text .

args.name: texttemplatesrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  texttemplate .

args.name: hovertextsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hovertext .

args.name: hovertemplatesrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hovertemplate .

args.name: textpositionsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  textposition .

texttemplatesrc.name: string
texttemplatesrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  texttemplate .

hovertextsrc.name: string
hovertextsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hovertext .

hovertemplatesrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hovertemplate .

textpositionsrc.name: string
textpositionsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  textposition .

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: selectedpoints
args.docString: Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x coordinates.

args.name: x0
args.docString: Alternate to `x`. Builds a linear space of x coordinates. Use with `dx` where `x0` is the starting coordinate and `dx` the step.

args.name: dx
args.docString: Sets the x coordinate step. See `x0` for more info.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y coordinates.

args.name: y0
args.docString: Alternate to `y`. Builds a linear space of y coordinates. Use with `dy` where `y0` is the starting coordinate and `dy` the step.

args.name: dy
args.docString: Sets the y coordinate step. See `y0` for more info.

args.name: xperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the x axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: yperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the y axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: xperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the x0 axis. When `x0period` is round number of weeks, the `x0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: yperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the y0 axis. When `y0period` is round number of weeks, the `y0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: xperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the x axis.

args.name: yperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the y axis.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets text elements associated with each (x,y) pair. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (x,y) coordinates. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: texttemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information text that appear on points. Note that this will override `textinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. Every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variables `value` and `label`.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Sets hover text elements associated with each (x,y) pair. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (x,y) coordinates. To be seen, trace `hoverinfo` must contain a *text* flag.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variables `value` and `label`. Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: textposition
args.docString: Specifies the location of the `text`. *inside* positions `text` inside, next to the bar end (rotated and scaled if needed). *outside* positions `text` outside, next to the bar end (scaled if needed), unless there is another bar stacked on this one, then the text gets pushed inside. *auto* tries to position `text` inside the bar, but if the bar is too small and no bar is stacked on this one the text is moved outside.

args.name: insidetextanchor
args.docString: Determines if texts are kept at center or start/end points in `textposition` *inside* mode.

args.name: textangle
args.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the bar. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically. With *auto* the texts may automatically be rotated to fit with the maximum size in bars.

args.name: textfont
args.docString: Sets the font used for `text`.

args.name: insidetextfont
args.docString: Sets the font used for `text` lying inside the bar.

args.name: outsidetextfont
args.docString: Sets the font used for `text` lying outside the bar.

args.name: constraintext
args.docString: Constrain the size of text inside or outside a bar to be no larger than the bar itself.

args.name: cliponaxis
args.docString: Determines whether the text nodes are clipped about the subplot axes. To show the text nodes above axis lines and tick labels, make sure to set `xaxis.layer` and `yaxis.layer` to *below traces*.

args.name: orientation
args.docString: Sets the orientation of the bars. With *v* (*h*), the value of the each bar spans along the vertical (horizontal).

args.name: base
args.docString: Sets where the bar base is drawn (in position axis units). In *stack* or *relative* barmode, traces that set *base* will be excluded and drawn in *overlay* mode instead.

args.name: offset
args.docString: Shifts the position where the bar is drawn (in position axis units). In *group* barmode, traces that set *offset* will be excluded and drawn in *overlay* mode instead.

args.name: width
args.docString: Sets the bar width (in position axis units).

args.name: offsetgroup
args.docString: Set several traces linked to the same position axis or matching axes to the same offsetgroup where bars of the same position coordinate will line up.

args.name: alignmentgroup
args.docString: Set several traces linked to the same position axis or matching axes to the same alignmentgroup. This controls whether bars compute their positional range dependently or independently.

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: xaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: yaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.

args.docString: Sets the x coordinate for single-box traces or the starting coordinate for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3. See overview for more info.

args.name: y0
args.docString: Sets the y coordinate for single-box traces or the starting coordinate for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3. See overview for more info.

args.name: dx
args.docString: Sets the x coordinate step for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3.

args.name: dy
args.docString: Sets the y coordinate step for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3.

args.name: xperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the x axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: yperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the y axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: xperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the x0 axis. When `x0period` is round number of weeks, the `x0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: yperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the y0 axis. When `y0period` is round number of weeks, the `y0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: xperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the x axis.

args.name: yperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the y axis.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover. For box traces, the name will also be used for the position coordinate, if `x` and `x0` (`y` and `y0` if horizontal) are missing and the position axis is categorical

args.name: q1
args.docString: Sets the Quartile 1 values. There should be as many items as the number of boxes desired.

args.name: median
args.docString: Sets the median values. There should be as many items as the number of boxes desired.

args.name: q3
args.docString: Sets the Quartile 3 values. There should be as many items as the number of boxes desired.

args.name: lowerfence
args.docString: Sets the lower fence values. There should be as many items as the number of boxes desired. This attribute has effect only under the q1/median/q3 signature. If `lowerfence` is not provided but a sample (in `y` or `x`) is set, we compute the lower as the last sample point below 1.5 times the IQR.

args.name: upperfence
args.docString: Sets the upper fence values. There should be as many items as the number of boxes desired. This attribute has effect only under the q1/median/q3 signature. If `upperfence` is not provided but a sample (in `y` or `x`) is set, we compute the lower as the last sample point above 1.5 times the IQR.

args.name: notched
args.docString: Determines whether or not notches are drawn. Notches displays a confidence interval around the median. We compute the confidence interval as median +/- 1.57 * IQR / sqrt(N), where IQR is the interquartile range and N is the sample size. If two boxes' notches do not overlap there is 95% confidence their medians differ. See https://sites.google.com/site/davidsstatistics/home/notched-box-plots for more info. Defaults to *false* unless `notchwidth` or `notchspan` is set.

args.name: notchwidth
args.docString: Sets the width of the notches relative to the box' width. For example, with 0, the notches are as wide as the box(es).

args.name: notchspan
args.docString: Sets the notch span from the boxes' `median` values. There should be as many items as the number of boxes desired. This attribute has effect only under the q1/median/q3 signature. If `notchspan` is not provided but a sample (in `y` or `x`) is set, we compute it as 1.57 * IQR / sqrt(N), where N is the sample size.

args.name: boxpoints
args.docString: If *outliers*, only the sample points lying outside the whiskers are shown If *suspectedoutliers*, the outlier points are shown and points either less than 4*Q1-3*Q3 or greater than 4*Q3-3*Q1 are highlighted (see `outliercolor`) If *all*, all sample points are shown If *false*, only the box(es) are shown with no sample points Defaults to *suspectedoutliers* when `marker.outliercolor` or `marker.line.outliercolor` is set. Defaults to *all* under the q1/median/q3 signature. Otherwise defaults to *outliers*.

args.name: jitter
args.docString: Sets the amount of jitter in the sample points drawn. If *0*, the sample points align along the distribution axis. If *1*, the sample points are drawn in a random jitter of width equal to the width of the box(es).

args.name: pointpos
args.docString: Sets the position of the sample points in relation to the box(es). If *0*, the sample points are places over the center of the box(es). Positive (negative) values correspond to positions to the right (left) for vertical boxes and above (below) for horizontal boxes

args.name: boxmean
args.docString: If *true*, the mean of the box(es)' underlying distribution is drawn as a dashed line inside the box(es). If *sd* the standard deviation is also drawn. Defaults to *true* when `mean` is set. Defaults to *sd* when `sd` is set Otherwise defaults to *false*.

args.name: mean
args.docString: Sets the mean values. There should be as many items as the number of boxes desired. This attribute has effect only under the q1/median/q3 signature. If `mean` is not provided but a sample (in `y` or `x`) is set, we compute the mean for each box using the sample values.

args.name: sd
args.docString: Sets the standard deviation values. There should be as many items as the number of boxes desired. This attribute has effect only under the q1/median/q3 signature. If `sd` is not provided but a sample (in `y` or `x`) is set, we compute the standard deviation for each box using the sample values.

args.name: orientation
args.docString: Sets the orientation of the box(es). If *v* (*h*), the distribution is visualized along the vertical (horizontal).

args.name: quartilemethod
args.docString: Sets the method used to compute the sample's Q1 and Q3 quartiles. The *linear* method uses the 25th percentile for Q1 and 75th percentile for Q3 as computed using method #10 (listed on http://www.amstat.org/publications/jse/v14n3/langford.html). The *exclusive* method uses the median to divide the ordered dataset into two halves if the sample is odd, it does not include the median in either half - Q1 is then the median of the lower half and Q3 the median of the upper half. The *inclusive* method also uses the median to divide the ordered dataset into two halves but if the sample is odd, it includes the median in both halves - Q1 is then the median of the lower half and Q3 the median of the upper half.

args.name: width
args.docString: Sets the width of the box in data coordinate If *0* (default value) the width is automatically selected based on the positions of other box traces in the same subplot.

args.name: fillcolor
args.docString: Sets the fill color. Defaults to a half-transparent variant of the line color, marker color, or marker line color, whichever is available.

args.name: whiskerwidth
args.docString: Sets the width of the whiskers relative to the box' width. For example, with 1, the whiskers are as wide as the box(es).

args.name: offsetgroup
args.docString: Set several traces linked to the same position axis or matching axes to the same offsetgroup where bars of the same position coordinate will line up.

args.name: alignmentgroup
args.docString: Set several traces linked to the same position axis or matching axes to the same alignmentgroup. This controls whether bars compute their positional range dependently or independently.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the text elements associated with each sample value. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (x,y) coordinates. To be seen, trace `hoverinfo` must contain a *text* flag.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: hoveron
args.docString: Do the hover effects highlight individual boxes  or sample points or both?

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: xaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: yaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.

args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  customdata .

args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  meta .

visible.name: enumerated
visible.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

showlegend.name: boolean
showlegend.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

legendgroup.name: string
legendgroup.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

opacity.name: number
opacity.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

uid.name: string
uid.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

ids.name: data_array
ids.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

customdata.name: data_array
customdata.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

meta.name: any
meta.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

selectedpoints.name: any
selectedpoints.docString: Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect.

hoverinfo.name: flaglist
hoverinfo.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

y.name: data_array
y.docString: Sets the y sample data or coordinates. See overview for more info.

x.name: data_array
x.docString: Sets the x sample data or coordinates. See overview for more info.

x0.name: any
x0.docString: Sets the x coordinate for single-box traces or the starting coordinate for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3. See overview for more info.

y0.name: any
y0.docString: Sets the y coordinate for single-box traces or the starting coordinate for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3. See overview for more info.

dx.name: number
dx.docString: Sets the x coordinate step for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3.

dy.name: number
dy.docString: Sets the y coordinate step for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3.

xperiod.name: any
xperiod.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the x axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the z data.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x coordinates.

args.name: x0
args.docString: Alternate to `x`. Builds a linear space of x coordinates. Use with `dx` where `x0` is the starting coordinate and `dx` the step.

args.name: dx
args.docString: Sets the x coordinate step. See `x0` for more info.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y coordinates.

args.name: y0
args.docString: Alternate to `y`. Builds a linear space of y coordinates. Use with `dy` where `y0` is the starting coordinate and `dy` the step.

args.name: dy
args.docString: Sets the y coordinate step. See `y0` for more info.

args.name: xperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the x axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: yperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the y axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: xperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the x0 axis. When `x0period` is round number of weeks, the `x0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: yperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the y0 axis. When `y0period` is round number of weeks, the `y0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: xperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the x axis.

args.name: yperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the y axis.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the text elements associated with each z value.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: transpose
args.docString: Transposes the z data.

args.name: xtype
args.docString: If *array*, the heatmap's x coordinates are given by *x* (the default behavior when `x` is provided). If *scaled*, the heatmap's x coordinates are given by *x0* and *dx* (the default behavior when `x` is not provided).

args.name: ytype
args.docString: If *array*, the heatmap's y coordinates are given by *y* (the default behavior when `y` is provided) If *scaled*, the heatmap's y coordinates are given by *y0* and *dy* (the default behavior when `y` is not provided)

args.name: zsmooth
args.docString: Picks a smoothing algorithm use to smooth `z` data.

args.name: hoverongaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the `z` data have hover labels associated with them.

args.name: connectgaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the `z` data are filled in. It is defaulted to true if `z` is a one dimensional array and `zsmooth` is not false; otherwise it is defaulted to false.

args.name: xgap
args.docString: Sets the horizontal gap (in pixels) between bricks.

args.name: ygap
args.docString: Sets the vertical gap (in pixels) between bricks.

args.name: zhoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. See: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: zauto
args.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here in `z`) or the bounds set in `zmin` and `zmax`  Defaults to `false` when `zmin` and `zmax` are set by the user.

args.name: zmin
args.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmax` must be set as well.

args.name: zmax
args.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmin` must be set as well.

args.name: zmid
args.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `zmin` and/or `zmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as in `z`. Has no effect when `zauto` is `false`.

args.name: colorscale
args.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`zmin` and `zmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

args.name: autocolorscale
args.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

args.name: reversescale
args.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `zmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `zmax` will correspond to the first color.

args.name: showscale
args.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

args.name: coloraxis
args.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: xaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: yaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.
