args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: selectedpoints
args.docString: Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the sample data to be binned on the x axis.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the sample data to be binned on the y axis.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets hover text elements associated with each bar. If a single string, the same string appears over all bars. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's coordinates.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: orientation
args.docString: Sets the orientation of the bars. With *v* (*h*), the value of the each bar spans along the vertical (horizontal).

args.name: histfunc
args.docString: Specifies the binning function used for this histogram trace. If *count*, the histogram values are computed by counting the number of values lying inside each bin. If *sum*, *avg*, *min*, *max*, the histogram values are computed using the sum, the average, the minimum or the maximum of the values lying inside each bin respectively.

args.name: histnorm
args.docString: Specifies the type of normalization used for this histogram trace. If **, the span of each bar corresponds to the number of occurrences (i.e. the number of data points lying inside the bins). If *percent* / *probability*, the span of each bar corresponds to the percentage / fraction of occurrences with respect to the total number of sample points (here, the sum of all bin HEIGHTS equals 100% / 1). If *density*, the span of each bar corresponds to the number of occurrences in a bin divided by the size of the bin interval (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals the total number of sample points). If *probability density*, the area of each bar corresponds to the probability that an event will fall into the corresponding bin (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals 1).

args.name: nbinsx
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `xbins.size` is provided.

args.name: nbinsy
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `ybins.size` is provided.

args.name: autobinx
args.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobinx` is not needed. However, we accept `autobinx: true` or `false` and will update `xbins` accordingly before deleting `autobinx` from the trace.

args.name: autobiny
args.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobiny` is not needed. However, we accept `autobiny: true` or `false` and will update `ybins` accordingly before deleting `autobiny` from the trace.

args.name: bingroup
args.docString: Set a group of histogram traces which will have compatible bin settings. Note that traces on the same subplot and with the same *orientation* under `barmode` *stack*, *relative* and *group* are forced into the same bingroup, Using `bingroup`, traces under `barmode` *overlay* and on different axes (of the same axis type) can have compatible bin settings. Note that histogram and histogram2d* trace can share the same `bingroup`

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variable `binNumber` Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: offsetgroup
args.docString: Set several traces linked to the same position axis or matching axes to the same offsetgroup where bars of the same position coordinate will line up.

args.name: alignmentgroup
args.docString: Set several traces linked to the same position axis or matching axes to the same alignmentgroup. This controls whether bars compute their positional range dependently or independently.

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: xaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: yaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.

visible.name: enumerated
visible.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

showlegend.name: boolean
showlegend.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

legendgroup.name: string
legendgroup.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

opacity.name: number
opacity.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

name.name: string
name.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

uid.name: string
uid.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

ids.name: data_array
ids.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

customdata.name: data_array
customdata.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

meta.name: any
meta.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

selectedpoints.name: any
selectedpoints.docString: Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect.

hoverinfo.name: flaglist
hoverinfo.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

x.name: data_array
x.docString: Sets the sample data to be binned on the x axis.

y.name: data_array
y.docString: Sets the sample data to be binned on the y axis.

text.name: string
text.docString: Sets hover text elements associated with each bar. If a single string, the same string appears over all bars. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's coordinates.

hovertext.name: string
hovertext.docString: Same as `text`.

orientation.name: enumerated
orientation.docString: Sets the orientation of the bars. With *v* (*h*), the value of the each bar spans along the vertical (horizontal).

histfunc.name: enumerated
histfunc.docString: Specifies the binning function used for this histogram trace. If *count*, the histogram values are computed by counting the number of values lying inside each bin. If *sum*, *avg*, *min*, *max*, the histogram values are computed using the sum, the average, the minimum or the maximum of the values lying inside each bin respectively.

histnorm.name: enumerated
histnorm.docString: Specifies the type of normalization used for this histogram trace. If **, the span of each bar corresponds to the number of occurrences (i.e. the number of data points lying inside the bins). If *percent* / *probability*, the span of each bar corresponds to the percentage / fraction of occurrences with respect to the total number of sample points (here, the sum of all bin HEIGHTS equals 100% / 1). If *density*, the span of each bar corresponds to the number of occurrences in a bin divided by the size of the bin interval (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals the total number of sample points). If *probability density*, the area of each bar corresponds to the probability that an event will fall into the corresponding bin (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals 1).

nbinsx.name: integer
nbinsx.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `xbins.size` is provided.

nbinsy.name: integer
nbinsy.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `ybins.size` is provided.

autobinx.name: boolean
autobinx.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobinx` is not needed. However, we accept `autobinx: true` or `false` and will update `xbins` accordingly before deleting `autobinx` from the trace.

autobiny.name: boolean
autobiny.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobiny` is not needed. However, we accept `autobiny: true` or `false` and will update `ybins` accordingly before deleting `autobiny` from the trace.

Note that histogram and histogram2d* trace can share the same `bingroup`

args.name: name

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the sample data to be binned on the x axis.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the sample data to be binned on the y axis.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the aggregation data.

args.name: histnorm
args.docString: Specifies the type of normalization used for this histogram trace. If **, the span of each bar corresponds to the number of occurrences (i.e. the number of data points lying inside the bins). If *percent* / *probability*, the span of each bar corresponds to the percentage / fraction of occurrences with respect to the total number of sample points (here, the sum of all bin HEIGHTS equals 100% / 1). If *density*, the span of each bar corresponds to the number of occurrences in a bin divided by the size of the bin interval (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals the total number of sample points). If *probability density*, the area of each bar corresponds to the probability that an event will fall into the corresponding bin (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals 1).

args.name: histfunc
args.docString: Specifies the binning function used for this histogram trace. If *count*, the histogram values are computed by counting the number of values lying inside each bin. If *sum*, *avg*, *min*, *max*, the histogram values are computed using the sum, the average, the minimum or the maximum of the values lying inside each bin respectively.

args.name: nbinsx
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `xbins.size` is provided.

args.name: nbinsy
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `ybins.size` is provided.

args.name: autobinx
args.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobinx` is not needed. However, we accept `autobinx: true` or `false` and will update `xbins` accordingly before deleting `autobinx` from the trace.

args.name: autobiny
args.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobiny` is not needed. However, we accept `autobiny: true` or `false` and will update `ybins` accordingly before deleting `autobiny` from the trace.

args.name: bingroup
args.docString: Set the `xbingroup` and `ybingroup` default prefix For example, setting a `bingroup` of *1* on two histogram2d traces will make them their x-bins and y-bins match separately.

args.name: xbingroup
args.docString: Set a group of histogram traces which will have compatible x-bin settings. Using `xbingroup`, histogram2d and histogram2dcontour traces  (on axes of the same axis type) can have compatible x-bin settings. Note that the same `xbingroup` value can be used to set (1D) histogram `bingroup`

args.name: ybingroup
args.docString: Set a group of histogram traces which will have compatible y-bin settings. Using `ybingroup`, histogram2d and histogram2dcontour traces  (on axes of the same axis type) can have compatible y-bin settings. Note that the same `ybingroup` value can be used to set (1D) histogram `bingroup`

args.name: xgap
args.docString: Sets the horizontal gap (in pixels) between bricks.

args.name: ygap
args.docString: Sets the vertical gap (in pixels) between bricks.

args.name: zsmooth
args.docString: Picks a smoothing algorithm use to smooth `z` data.

args.name: zhoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. See: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variable `z` Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: zauto
args.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here in `z`) or the bounds set in `zmin` and `zmax`  Defaults to `false` when `zmin` and `zmax` are set by the user.

args.name: zmin
args.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmax` must be set as well.

args.name: zmax
args.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmin` must be set as well.

args.name: zmid
args.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `zmin` and/or `zmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as in `z`. Has no effect when `zauto` is `false`.

args.name: colorscale
args.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`zmin` and `zmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

args.name: autocolorscale
args.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

args.name: reversescale
args.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `zmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `zmax` will correspond to the first color.

args.name: showscale
args.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

args.name: coloraxis
args.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: xaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: yaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.

If *probability density*, the area of each bar corresponds to the probability that an event will fall into the corresponding bin (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals 1).

histfunc.name: enumerated
histfunc.docString: Specifies the binning function used for this histogram trace. If *count*, the histogram values are computed by counting the number of values lying inside each bin. If *sum*, *avg*, *min*, *max*, the histogram values are computed using the sum, the average, the minimum or the maximum of the values lying inside each bin respectively.

nbinsx.name: integer
nbinsx.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `xbins.size` is provided.

nbinsy.name: integer
nbinsy.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `ybins.size` is provided.

autobinx.name: boolean
autobinx.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobinx` is not needed. However, we accept `autobinx: true` or `false` and will update `xbins` accordingly before deleting `autobinx` from the trace.

autobiny.name: boolean
autobiny.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobiny` is not needed. However, we accept `autobiny: true` or `false` and will update `ybins` accordingly before deleting `autobiny` from the trace.

bingroup.name: string
bingroup.docString: Set the `xbingroup` and `ybingroup` default prefix For example, setting a `bingroup` of *1* on two histogram2d traces will make them their x-bins and y-bins match separately.

xbingroup.name: string
xbingroup.docString: Set a group of histogram traces which will have compatible x-bin settings. Using `xbingroup`, histogram2d and histogram2dcontour traces  (on axes of the same axis type) can have compatible x-bin settings. Note that the same `xbingroup` value can be used to set (1D) histogram `bingroup`

ybingroup.name: string
ybingroup.docString: Set a group of histogram traces which will have compatible y-bin settings. Using `ybingroup`, histogram2d and histogram2dcontour traces  (on axes of the same axis type) can have compatible y-bin settings. Note that the same `ybingroup` value can be used to set (1D) histogram `bingroup`

xgap.name: number
xgap.docString: Sets the horizontal gap (in pixels) between bricks.

ygap.name: number
ygap.docString: Sets the vertical gap (in pixels) between bricks.

zsmooth.name: enumerated
zsmooth.docString: Picks a smoothing algorithm use to smooth `z` data.

zhoverformat.name: string
zhoverformat.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. See: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format

hovertemplate.name: string
hovertemplate.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variable `z` Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

showlegend.name: boolean
showlegend.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

zauto.name: boolean
zauto.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here in `z`) or the bounds set in `zmin` and `zmax`  Defaults to `false` when `zmin` and `zmax` are set by the user.

zmin.name: number
zmin.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmax` must be set as well.

zmax.name: number
zmax.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmin` must be set as well.

zmid.name: number
zmid.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `zmin` and/or `zmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as in `z`. Has no effect when `zauto` is `false`.

colorscale.name: colorscale
colorscale.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`zmin` and `zmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

autocolorscale.name: boolean
autocolorscale.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

reversescale.name: boolean
reversescale.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `zmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `zmax` will correspond to the first color.

showscale.name: boolean
showscale.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

coloraxis.name: subplotid
coloraxis.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

xcalendar.name: enumerated
xcalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

ycalendar.name: enumerated
ycalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

xaxis.name: subplotid
xaxis.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

yaxis.name: subplotid
yaxis.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.

idssrc.name: string
idssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ids .

customdatasrc.name: string
customdatasrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  customdata .

metasrc.name: string
metasrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  meta .

hoverinfosrc.name: string
hoverinfosrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hoverinfo .

xsrc.name: string
xsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  x .

ysrc.name: string
ysrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  y .

zsrc.name: string
zsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  z .

hovertemplatesrc.name: string
hovertemplatesrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hovertemplate .

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the sample data to be binned on the x axis.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the sample data to be binned on the y axis.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the aggregation data.

args.name: histnorm
args.docString: Specifies the type of normalization used for this histogram trace. If **, the span of each bar corresponds to the number of occurrences (i.e. the number of data points lying inside the bins). If *percent* / *probability*, the span of each bar corresponds to the percentage / fraction of occurrences with respect to the total number of sample points (here, the sum of all bin HEIGHTS equals 100% / 1). If *density*, the span of each bar corresponds to the number of occurrences in a bin divided by the size of the bin interval (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals the total number of sample points). If *probability density*, the area of each bar corresponds to the probability that an event will fall into the corresponding bin (here, the sum of all bin AREAS equals 1).

args.name: histfunc
args.docString: Specifies the binning function used for this histogram trace. If *count*, the histogram values are computed by counting the number of values lying inside each bin. If *sum*, *avg*, *min*, *max*, the histogram values are computed using the sum, the average, the minimum or the maximum of the values lying inside each bin respectively.

args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `xbins.size` is provided.

args.name: nbinsy
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of desired bins. This value will be used in an algorithm that will decide the optimal bin size such that the histogram best visualizes the distribution of the data. Ignored if `ybins.size` is provided.

args.name: autobinx
args.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobinx` is not needed. However, we accept `autobinx: true` or `false` and will update `xbins` accordingly before deleting `autobinx` from the trace.

args.name: autobiny
args.docString: Obsolete: since v1.42 each bin attribute is auto-determined separately and `autobiny` is not needed. However, we accept `autobiny: true` or `false` and will update `ybins` accordingly before deleting `autobiny` from the trace.

args.name: bingroup
args.docString: Set the `xbingroup` and `ybingroup` default prefix For example, setting a `bingroup` of *1* on two histogram2d traces will make them their x-bins and y-bins match separately.

args.name: xbingroup
args.docString: Set a group of histogram traces which will have compatible x-bin settings. Using `xbingroup`, histogram2d and histogram2dcontour traces  (on axes of the same axis type) can have compatible x-bin settings. Note that the same `xbingroup` value can be used to set (1D) histogram `bingroup`

args.name: ybingroup
args.docString: Set a group of histogram traces which will have compatible y-bin settings. Using `ybingroup`, histogram2d and histogram2dcontour traces  (on axes of the same axis type) can have compatible y-bin settings. Note that the same `ybingroup` value can be used to set (1D) histogram `bingroup`

args.name: autocontour
args.docString: Determines whether or not the contour level attributes are picked by an algorithm. If *true*, the number of contour levels can be set in `ncontours`. If *false*, set the contour level attributes in `contours`.

args.name: ncontours
args.docString: Sets the maximum number of contour levels. The actual number of contours will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to the value of `ncontours`. Has an effect only if `autocontour` is *true* or if `contours.size` is missing.

args.name: zhoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. See: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format

zmin.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmax` must be set as well.

zmax.name: number
zmax.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmin` must be set as well.

zmid.name: number
zmid.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `zmin` and/or `zmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as in `z`. Has no effect when `zauto` is `false`.

colorscale.name: colorscale
colorscale.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`zmin` and `zmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

autocolorscale.name: boolean
autocolorscale.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

reversescale.name: boolean
reversescale.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `zmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `zmax` will correspond to the first color.

showscale.name: boolean
showscale.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

coloraxis.name: subplotid
coloraxis.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

xcalendar.name: enumerated
xcalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

ycalendar.name: enumerated
ycalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

xaxis.name: subplotid
xaxis.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

yaxis.name: subplotid
yaxis.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the z data.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x coordinates.

args.name: x0
args.docString: Alternate to `x`. Builds a linear space of x coordinates. Use with `dx` where `x0` is the starting coordinate and `dx` the step.

args.name: dx
args.docString: Sets the x coordinate step. See `x0` for more info.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y coordinates.

args.name: y0
args.docString: Alternate to `y`. Builds a linear space of y coordinates. Use with `dy` where `y0` is the starting coordinate and `dy` the step.

args.name: dy
args.docString: Sets the y coordinate step. See `y0` for more info.

args.name: xperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the x axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: yperiod
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the period positioning in milliseconds or *M<n>* on the y axis. Special values in the form of *M<n>* could be used to declare the number of months. In this case `n` must be a positive integer.

args.name: xperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the x0 axis. When `x0period` is round number of weeks, the `x0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: yperiod0
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the base for period positioning in milliseconds or date string on the y0 axis. When `y0period` is round number of weeks, the `y0period0` by default would be on a Sunday i.e. 2000-01-02, otherwise it would be at 2000-01-01.

args.name: xperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the x axis.

args.name: yperiodalignment
args.docString: Only relevant when the axis `type` is *date*. Sets the alignment of data points on the y axis.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the text elements associated with each z value.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: transpose
args.docString: Transposes the z data.

args.name: xtype
args.docString: If *array*, the heatmap's x coordinates are given by *x* (the default behavior when `x` is provided). If *scaled*, the heatmap's x coordinates are given by *x0* and *dx* (the default behavior when `x` is not provided).

args.name: ytype
args.docString: If *array*, the heatmap's y coordinates are given by *y* (the default behavior when `y` is provided) If *scaled*, the heatmap's y coordinates are given by *y0* and *dy* (the default behavior when `y` is not provided)

args.name: zhoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. See: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: hoverongaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the `z` data have hover labels associated with them.

args.name: connectgaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the `z` data are filled in. It is defaulted to true if `z` is a one dimensional array otherwise it is defaulted to false.

args.name: fillcolor
args.docString: Sets the fill color if `contours.type` is *constraint*. Defaults to a half-transparent variant of the line color, marker color, or marker line color, whichever is available.

args.name: autocontour
args.docString: Determines whether or not the contour level attributes are picked by an algorithm. If *true*, the number of contour levels can be set in `ncontours`. If *false*, set the contour level attributes in `contours`.

args.name: ncontours
args.docString: Sets the maximum number of contour levels. The actual number of contours will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to the value of `ncontours`. Has an effect only if `autocontour` is *true* or if `contours.size` is missing.

args.name: zauto
args.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here in `z`) or the bounds set in `zmin` and `zmax`  Defaults to `false` when `zmin` and `zmax` are set by the user.

args.name: zmin
args.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmax` must be set as well.

args.name: zmax
args.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as in `z` and if set, `zmin` must be set as well.

args.name: zmid
args.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `zmin` and/or `zmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as in `z`. Has no effect when `zauto` is `false`.

args.name: colorscale
args.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`zmin` and `zmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

args.name: autocolorscale
args.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

args.name: reversescale
args.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `zmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `zmax` will correspond to the first color.

args.name: showscale
args.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

args.name: coloraxis
args.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: xaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: yaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: selectedpoints
args.docString: Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: a
args.docString: Sets the quantity of component `a` in each data point. If `a`, `b`, and `c` are all provided, they need not be normalized, only the relative values matter. If only two arrays are provided they must be normalized to match `ternary<i>.sum`.

args.name: b
args.docString: Sets the quantity of component `a` in each data point. If `a`, `b`, and `c` are all provided, they need not be normalized, only the relative values matter. If only two arrays are provided they must be normalized to match `ternary<i>.sum`.

args.name: c
args.docString: Sets the quantity of component `a` in each data point. If `a`, `b`, and `c` are all provided, they need not be normalized, only the relative values matter. If only two arrays are provided they must be normalized to match `ternary<i>.sum`.

args.name: sum
args.docString: The number each triplet should sum to, if only two of `a`, `b`, and `c` are provided. This overrides `ternary<i>.sum` to normalize this specific trace, but does not affect the values displayed on the axes. 0 (or missing) means to use ternary<i>.sum

args.name: mode
args.docString: Determines the drawing mode for this scatter trace. If the provided `mode` includes *text* then the `text` elements appear at the coordinates. Otherwise, the `text` elements appear on hover. If there are less than 20 points and the trace is not stacked then the default is *lines+markers*. Otherwise, *lines*.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets text elements associated with each (a,b,c) point. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of strings, the items are mapped in order to the the data points in (a,b,c). If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: texttemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information text that appear on points. Note that this will override `textinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. Every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variables `a`, `b`, `c` and `text`.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Sets hover text elements associated with each (a,b,c) point. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of strings, the items are mapped in order to the the data points in (a,b,c). To be seen, trace `hoverinfo` must contain a *text* flag.

args.name: connectgaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the provided data arrays are connected.

args.name: cliponaxis
args.docString: Determines whether or not markers and text nodes are clipped about the subplot axes. To show markers and text nodes above axis lines and tick labels, make sure to set `xaxis.layer` and `yaxis.layer` to *below traces*.

args.name: fill
args.docString: Sets the area to fill with a solid color. Use with `fillcolor` if not *none*. scatterternary has a subset of the options available to scatter. *toself* connects the endpoints of the trace (or each segment of the trace if it has gaps) into a closed shape. *tonext* fills the space between two traces if one completely encloses the other (eg consecutive contour lines), and behaves like *toself* if there is no trace before it. *tonext* should not be used if one trace does not enclose the other.

args.name: fillcolor
args.docString: Sets the fill color. Defaults to a half-transparent variant of the line color, marker color, or marker line color, whichever is available.

args.name: textfont
args.docString: Sets the text font.

args.name: textposition
args.docString: Sets the positions of the `text` elements with respects to the (x,y) coordinates.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: hoveron
args.docString: Do the hover effects highlight individual points (markers or line points) or do they highlight filled regions? If the fill is *toself* or *tonext* and there are no markers or text, then the default is *fills*, otherwise it is *points*.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: subplot
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's data coordinates and a ternary subplot. If *ternary* (the default value), the data refer to `layout.ternary`. If *ternary2*, the data refer to `layout.ternary2`, and so on.

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: selectedpoints
args.docString: Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y sample data or coordinates. See overview for more info.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x sample data or coordinates. See overview for more info.

args.name: x0
args.docString: Sets the x coordinate for single-box traces or the starting coordinate for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3. See overview for more info.

args.name: y0
args.docString: Sets the y coordinate for single-box traces or the starting coordinate for multi-box traces set using q1/median/q3. See overview for more info.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover. For violin traces, the name will also be used for the position coordinate, if `x` and `x0` (`y` and `y0` if horizontal) are missing and the position axis is categorical. Note that the trace name is also used as a default value for attribute `scalegroup` (please see its description for details).

args.name: orientation
args.docString: Sets the orientation of the violin(s). If *v* (*h*), the distribution is visualized along the vertical (horizontal).

args.name: bandwidth
args.docString: Sets the bandwidth used to compute the kernel density estimate. By default, the bandwidth is determined by Silverman's rule of thumb.

args.name: scalegroup
args.docString: If there are multiple violins that should be sized according to to some metric (see `scalemode`), link them by providing a non-empty group id here shared by every trace in the same group. If a violin's `width` is undefined, `scalegroup` will default to the trace's name. In this case, violins with the same names will be linked together

args.name: scalemode
args.docString: Sets the metric by which the width of each violin is determined.*width* means each violin has the same (max) width*count* means the violins are scaled by the number of sample points makingup each violin.

args.name: spanmode
args.docString: Sets the method by which the span in data space where the density function will be computed. *soft* means the span goes from the sample's minimum value minus two bandwidths to the sample's maximum value plus two bandwidths. *hard* means the span goes from the sample's minimum to its maximum value. For custom span settings, use mode *manual* and fill in the `span` attribute.

args.name: span
args.docString: Sets the span in data space for which the density function will be computed. Has an effect only when `spanmode` is set to *manual*.

args.name: fillcolor
args.docString: Sets the fill color. Defaults to a half-transparent variant of the line color, marker color, or marker line color, whichever is available.

args.name: points
args.docString: If *outliers*, only the sample points lying outside the whiskers are shown If *suspectedoutliers*, the outlier points are shown and points either less than 4*Q1-3*Q3 or greater than 4*Q3-3*Q1 are highlighted (see `outliercolor`) If *all*, all sample points are shown If *false*, only the violins are shown with no sample points. Defaults to *suspectedoutliers* when `marker.outliercolor` or `marker.line.outliercolor` is set, otherwise defaults to *outliers*.

args.name: jitter
args.docString: Sets the amount of jitter in the sample points drawn. If *0*, the sample points align along the distribution axis. If *1*, the sample points are drawn in a random jitter of width equal to the width of the violins.

args.name: pointpos
args.docString: Sets the position of the sample points in relation to the violins. If *0*, the sample points are places over the center of the violins. Positive (negative) values correspond to positions to the right (left) for vertical violins and above (below) for horizontal violins.

args.name: width
args.docString: Sets the width of the violin in data coordinates. If *0* (default value) the width is automatically selected based on the positions of other violin traces in the same subplot.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the text elements associated with each sample value. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (x,y) coordinates. To be seen, trace `hoverinfo` must contain a *text* flag.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: side
args.docString: Determines on which side of the position value the density function making up one half of a violin is plotted. Useful when comparing two violin traces under *overlay* mode, where one trace has `side` set to *positive* and the other to *negative*.

args.name: offsetgroup
args.docString: Set several traces linked to the same position axis or matching axes to the same offsetgroup where bars of the same position coordinate will line up.

args.name: alignmentgroup
args.docString: Set several traces linked to the same position axis or matching axes to the same alignmentgroup. This controls whether bars compute their positional range dependently or independently.

args.name: hoveron
args.docString: Do the hover effects highlight individual violins or sample points or the kernel density estimate or any combination of them?

args.name: xaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D cartesian x axis. If *x* (the default value), the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis`. If *x2*, the x coordinates refer to `layout.xaxis2`, and so on.

args.name: yaxis
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D cartesian y axis. If *y* (the default value), the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis`. If *y2*, the y coordinates refer to `layout.yaxis2`, and so on.
