args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: labels
args.docString: Sets the sector labels. If `labels` entries are duplicated, we sum associated `values` or simply count occurrences if `values` is not provided. For other array attributes (including color) we use the first non-empty entry among all occurrences of the label.

args.name: label0
args.docString: Alternate to `labels`. Builds a numeric set of labels. Use with `dlabel` where `label0` is the starting label and `dlabel` the step.

args.name: dlabel
args.docString: Sets the label step. See `label0` for more info.

args.name: values
args.docString: Sets the values of the sectors. If omitted, we count occurrences of each label.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets text elements associated with each sector. If trace `textinfo` contains a *text* flag, these elements will be seen on the chart. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Sets hover text elements associated with each sector. If a single string, the same string appears for all data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order of this trace's sectors. To be seen, trace `hoverinfo` must contain a *text* flag.

args.name: scalegroup
args.docString: If there are multiple funnelareas that should be sized according to their totals, link them by providing a non-empty group id here shared by every trace in the same group.

args.name: textinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on the graph.

args.name: texttemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information text that appear on points. Note that this will override `textinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. args.name: hovertemplate

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the trace.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: transform
args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x coordinates.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y coordinates.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the z coordinates.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets text elements associated with each (x,y,z) triplet. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (x,y,z) coordinates. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: texttemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information text that appear on points. Note that this will override `textinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. Every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Sets text elements associated with each (x,y,z) triplet. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (x,y,z) coordinates. To be seen, trace `hoverinfo` must contain a *text* flag.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: mode
args.docString: Determines the drawing mode for this scatter trace. If the provided `mode` includes *text* then the `text` elements appear at the coordinates. Otherwise, the `text` elements appear on hover. If there are less than 20 points and the trace is not stacked then the default is *lines+markers*. Otherwise, *lines*.

args.name: surfaceaxis
args.docString: If *-1*, the scatter points are not fill with a surface If *0*, *1*, *2*, the scatter points are filled with a Delaunay surface about the x, y, z respectively.

args.name: surfacecolor
args.docString: Sets the surface fill color.

args.name: connectgaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the provided data arrays are connected.

args.name: textposition
args.docString: Sets the positions of the `text` elements with respects to the (x,y) coordinates.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: zcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `z` date data.

args.name: scene
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's 3D coordinate system and a 3D scene. If *scene* (the default value), the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene`. If *scene2*, the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene2`, and so on.

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the z coordinates.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x coordinates.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y coordinates.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the text elements associated with each z value. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: connectgaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the `z` data are filled in.

args.name: surfacecolor
args.docString: Sets the surface color values, used for setting a color scale independent of `z`.

args.name: cauto
args.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here z or surfacecolor) or the bounds set in `cmin` and `cmax`  Defaults to `false` when `cmin` and `cmax` are set by the user.

args.name: cmin
args.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as z or surfacecolor and if set, `cmax` must be set as well.

args.name: cmax
args.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as z or surfacecolor and if set, `cmin` must be set as well.

args.name: cmid
args.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `cmin` and/or `cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as z or surfacecolor. Has no effect when `cauto` is `false`.

args.name: colorscale
args.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`cmin` and `cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

args.name: autocolorscale
args.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

args.name: reversescale
args.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `cmax` will correspond to the first color.

args.name: showscale
args.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

args.name: coloraxis
args.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

args.name: hidesurface
args.docString: Determines whether or not a surface is drawn. For example, set `hidesurface` to *false* `contours.x.show` to *true* and `contours.y.show` to *true* to draw a wire frame plot.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the surface. Please note that in the case of using high `opacity` values for example a value greater than or equal to 0.5 on two surfaces (and 0.25 with four surfaces), an overlay of multiple transparent surfaces may not perfectly be sorted in depth by the webgl API. This behavior may be improved in the near future and is subject to change.

args.name: opacityscale
args.docString: Sets the opacityscale. The opacityscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an opacity value. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 1], [0.5, 0.2], [1, 1]]` means that higher/lower values would have higher opacity values and those in the middle would be more transparent Alternatively, `opacityscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: 'min', 'max', 'extremes' and 'uniform'. The default is 'uniform'.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: zcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `z` date data.

args.name: scene
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's 3D coordinate system and a 3D scene. If *scene* (the default value), the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene`. If *scene2*, the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene2`, and so on.

To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

z.name: data_array
z.docString: Sets the z coordinates.

x.name: data_array
x.docString: Sets the x coordinates.

y.name: data_array
y.docString: Sets the y coordinates.

text.name: string
text.docString: Sets the text elements associated with each z value. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

hovertext.name: string
hovertext.docString: Same as `text`.

hovertemplate.name: string
hovertemplate.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

connectgaps.name: boolean
connectgaps.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the `z` data are filled in.

surfacecolor.name: data_array
surfacecolor.docString: Sets the surface color values, used for setting a color scale independent of `z`.

cauto.name: boolean
cauto.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here z or surfacecolor) or the bounds set in `cmin` and `cmax`  Defaults to `false` when `cmin` and `cmax` are set by the user.

cmin.name: number
cmin.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as z or surfacecolor and if set, `cmax` must be set as well.

cmax.name: number
cmax.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as z or surfacecolor and if set, `cmin` must be set as well.

cmid.name: number
cmid.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `cmin` and/or `cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as z or surfacecolor. Has no effect when `cauto` is `false`.

colorscale.name: colorscale
colorscale.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`cmin` and `cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

autocolorscale.name: boolean
autocolorscale.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

reversescale.name: boolean
reversescale.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `cmax` will correspond to the first color.

showscale.name: boolean
showscale.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

coloraxis.name: subplotid
coloraxis.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

hidesurface.name: boolean
hidesurface.docString: Determines whether or not a surface is drawn. For example, set `hidesurface` to *false* `contours.x.show` to *true* and `contours.y.show` to *true* to draw a wire frame plot.

opacity.name: number
opacity.docString: Sets the opacity of the surface. Please note that in the case of using high `opacity` values for example a value greater than or equal to 0.5 on two surfaces (and 0.25 with four surfaces), an overlay of multiple transparent surfaces may not perfectly be sorted in depth by the webgl API. This behavior may be improved in the near future and is subject to change.

opacityscale.name: any
opacityscale.docString: Sets the opacityscale. The opacityscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an opacity value. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 1], [0.5, 0.2], [1, 1]]` means that higher/lower values would have higher opacity values and those in the middle would be more transparent Alternatively, `opacityscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: 'min', 'max', 'extremes' and 'uniform'. The default is 'uniform'.

hoverinfo.name: flaglist
hoverinfo.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

showlegend.name: boolean
showlegend.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

xcalendar.name: enumerated
xcalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

ycalendar.name: enumerated
ycalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

zcalendar.name: enumerated
zcalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `z` date data.

scene.name: subplotid
scene.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's 3D coordinate system and a 3D scene. If *scene* (the default value), the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene`. If *scene2*, the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene2`, and so on.

idssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ids .

customdatasrc.name: string
customdatasrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  customdata .

metasrc.name: string
metasrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  meta .

zsrc.name: string
zsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  z .

xsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  x .

hovertextsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hovertext .

hovertemplatesrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  hovertemplate .

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the X coordinates of the vertices on X axis.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the Y coordinates of the vertices on Y axis.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the Z coordinates of the vertices on Z axis.

args.name: value
args.docString: Sets the 4th dimension (value) of the vertices.

args.name: isomin
args.docString: Sets the minimum boundary for iso-surface plot.

args.name: isomax
args.docString: Sets the maximum boundary for iso-surface plot.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the text elements associated with the vertices. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: cauto
args.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here `value`) or the bounds set in `cmin` and `cmax`  Defaults to `false` when `cmin` and `cmax` are set by the user.

args.name: cmin
args.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as `value` and if set, `cmax` must be set as well.

args.name: cmax
args.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as `value` and if set, `cmin` must be set as well.

args.name: cmid
args.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `cmin` and/or `cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as `value`. Has no effect when `cauto` is `false`.

args.name: colorscale
args.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`cmin` and `cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

args.name: autocolorscale
args.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

args.name: reversescale
args.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `cmax` will correspond to the first color.

args.name: showscale
args.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

args.name: coloraxis
args.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the surface. Please note that in the case of using high `opacity` values for example a value greater than or equal to 0.5 on two surfaces (and 0.25 with four surfaces), an overlay of multiple transparent surfaces may not perfectly be sorted in depth by the webgl API. This behavior may be improved in the near future and is subject to change.

args.name: opacityscale
args.docString: Sets the opacityscale. The opacityscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an opacity value. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 1], [0.5, 0.2], [1, 1]]` means that higher/lower values would have higher opacity values and those in the middle would be more transparent Alternatively, `opacityscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: 'min', 'max', 'extremes' and 'uniform'. The default is 'uniform'.

args.name: flatshading
args.docString: Determines whether or not normal smoothing is applied to the meshes, creating meshes with an angular, low-poly look via flat reflections.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: scene
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's 3D coordinate system and a 3D scene. If *scene* (the default value), the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene`. If *scene2*, the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene2`, and so on.

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the X coordinates of the vertices. The nth element of vectors `x`, `y` and `z` jointly represent the X, Y and Z coordinates of the nth vertex.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the Y coordinates of the vertices. The nth element of vectors `x`, `y` and `z` jointly represent the X, Y and Z coordinates of the nth vertex.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the Z coordinates of the vertices. The nth element of vectors `x`, `y` and `z` jointly represent the X, Y and Z coordinates of the nth vertex.

args.name: i
args.docString: A vector of vertex indices, i.e. integer values between 0 and the length of the vertex vectors, representing the *first* vertex of a triangle. For example, `{i[m], j[m], k[m]}` together represent face m (triangle m) in the mesh, where `i[m] = n` points to the triplet `{x[n], y[n], z[n]}` in the vertex arrays. Therefore, each element in `i` represents a point in space, which is the first vertex of a triangle.

args.name: j
args.docString: A vector of vertex indices, i.e. integer values between 0 and the length of the vertex vectors, representing the *second* vertex of a triangle. For example, `{i[m], j[m], k[m]}`  together represent face m (triangle m) in the mesh, where `j[m] = n` points to the triplet `{x[n], y[n], z[n]}` in the vertex arrays. Therefore, each element in `j` represents a point in space, which is the second vertex of a triangle.

args.name: k
args.docString: A vector of vertex indices, i.e. integer values between 0 and the length of the vertex vectors, representing the *third* vertex of a triangle. For example, `{i[m], j[m], k[m]}` together represent face m (triangle m) in the mesh, where `k[m] = n` points to the triplet  `{x[n], y[n], z[n]}` in the vertex arrays. Therefore, each element in `k` represents a point in space, which is the third vertex of a triangle.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the text elements associated with the vertices. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: delaunayaxis
args.docString: Sets the Delaunay axis, which is the axis that is perpendicular to the surface of the Delaunay triangulation. It has an effect if `i`, `j`, `k` are not provided and `alphahull` is set to indicate Delaunay triangulation.

args.name: alphahull
args.docString: Determines how the mesh surface triangles are derived from the set of vertices (points) represented by the `x`, `y` and `z` arrays, if the `i`, `j`, `k` arrays are not supplied. For general use of `mesh3d` it is preferred that `i`, `j`, `k` are supplied. If *-1*, Delaunay triangulation is used, which is mainly suitable if the mesh is a single, more or less layer surface that is perpendicular to `delaunayaxis`. In case the `delaunayaxis` intersects the mesh surface at more than one point it will result triangles that are very long in the dimension of `delaunayaxis`. If *>0*, the alpha-shape algorithm is used. In this case, the positive `alphahull` value signals the use of the alpha-shape algorithm, _and_ its value acts as the parameter for the mesh fitting. If *0*,  the convex-hull algorithm is used. It is suitable for convex bodies or if the intention is to enclose the `x`, `y` and `z` point set into a convex hull.

args.name: intensity
args.docString: Sets the intensity values for vertices or cells as defined by `intensitymode`. It can be used for plotting fields on meshes.

args.name: intensitymode
args.docString: Determines the source of `intensity` values.

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets the color of the whole mesh

args.name: vertexcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of each vertex Overrides *color*. While Red, green and blue colors are in the range of 0 and 255; in the case of having vertex color data in RGBA format, the alpha color should be normalized to be between 0 and 1.

args.name: facecolor
args.docString: Sets the color of each face Overrides *color* and *vertexcolor*.

args.name: cauto
args.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here `intensity`) or the bounds set in `cmin` and `cmax`  Defaults to `false` when `cmin` and `cmax` are set by the user.

args.name: cmax

args.name: xcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

args.name: ycalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

args.name: zcalendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `z` date data.

args.name: scene
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's 3D coordinate system and a 3D scene. If *scene* (the default value), the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene`. If *scene2*, the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene2`, and so on.

visible.name: enumerated
visible.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

legendgroup.name: string
legendgroup.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

name.name: string
name.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

uid.name: string
uid.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

ids.name: data_array
ids.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

customdata.name: data_array
customdata.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

meta.name: any
meta.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

x.name: data_array
x.docString: Sets the X coordinates of the vertices. The nth element of vectors `x`, `y` and `z` jointly represent the X, Y and Z coordinates of the nth vertex.

y.name: data_array
y.docString: Sets the Y coordinates of the vertices. The nth element of vectors `x`, `y` and `z` jointly represent the X, Y and Z coordinates of the nth vertex.

z.name: data_array
z.docString: Sets the Z coordinates of the vertices. The nth element of vectors `x`, `y` and `z` jointly represent the X, Y and Z coordinates of the nth vertex.

i.name: data_array
i.docString: A vector of vertex indices, i.e. integer values between 0 and the length of the vertex vectors, representing the *first* vertex of a triangle. For example, `{i[m], j[m], k[m]}` together represent face m (triangle m) in the mesh, where `i[m] = n` points to the triplet `{x[n], y[n], z[n]}` in the vertex arrays. Therefore, each element in `i` represents a point in space, which is the first vertex of a triangle.

j.name: data_array
j.docString: A vector of vertex indices, i.e. integer values between 0 and the length of the vertex vectors, representing the *second* vertex of a triangle. For example, `{i[m], j[m], k[m]}`  together represent face m (triangle m) in the mesh, where `j[m] = n` points to the triplet `{x[n], y[n], z[n]}` in the vertex arrays. Therefore, each element in `j` represents a point in space, which is the second vertex of a triangle.

k.name: data_array
k.docString: A vector of vertex indices, i.e. integer values between 0 and the length of the vertex vectors, representing the *third* vertex of a triangle. For example, `{i[m], j[m], k[m]}` together represent face m (triangle m) in the mesh, where `k[m] = n` points to the triplet  `{x[n], y[n], z[n]}` in the vertex arrays. Therefore, each element in `k` represents a point in space, which is the third vertex of a triangle.

text.name: string
text.docString: Sets the text elements associated with the vertices. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

hovertext.name: string
hovertext.docString: Same as `text`.

hovertemplate.name: string
hovertemplate.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

delaunayaxis.name: enumerated
delaunayaxis.docString: Sets the Delaunay axis, which is the axis that is perpendicular to the surface of the Delaunay triangulation. It has an effect if `i`, `j`, `k` are not provided and `alphahull` is set to indicate Delaunay triangulation.

alphahull.name: number
alphahull.docString: Determines how the mesh surface triangles are derived from the set of vertices (points) represented by the `x`, `y` and `z` arrays, if the `i`, `j`, `k` arrays are not supplied. For general use of `mesh3d` it is preferred that `i`, `j`, `k` are supplied. If *-1*, Delaunay triangulation is used, which is mainly suitable if the mesh is a single, more or less layer surface that is perpendicular to `delaunayaxis`. In case the `delaunayaxis` intersects the mesh surface at more than one point it will result triangles that are very long in the dimension of `delaunayaxis`. If *>0*, the alpha-shape algorithm is used. In this case, the positive `alphahull` value signals the use of the alpha-shape algorithm, _and_ its value acts as the parameter for the mesh fitting. If *0*,  the convex-hull algorithm is used. It is suitable for convex bodies or if the intention is to enclose the `x`, `y` and `z` point set into a convex hull.

intensity.name: data_array
intensity.docString: Sets the intensity values for vertices or cells as defined by `intensitymode`. It can be used for plotting fields on meshes.

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets the color of the whole mesh

vertexcolor.name: data_array
vertexcolor.docString: Sets the color of each vertex Overrides *color*. While Red, green and blue colors are in the range of 0 and 255; in the case of having vertex color data in RGBA format, the alpha color should be normalized to be between 0 and 1.

facecolor.name: data_array
facecolor.docString: Sets the color of each face Overrides *color* and *vertexcolor*.

cauto.name: boolean
cauto.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here `intensity`) or the bounds set in `cmin` and `cmax`  Defaults to `false` when `cmin` and `cmax` are set by the user.

cmin.name: number
cmin.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as `intensity` and if set, `cmax` must be set as well.

cmax.name: number
cmax.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as `intensity` and if set, `cmin` must be set as well.

cmid.name: number
cmid.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `cmin` and/or `cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as `intensity`. Has no effect when `cauto` is `false`.

colorscale.name: colorscale
colorscale.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`cmin` and `cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

autocolorscale.name: boolean
autocolorscale.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

reversescale.name: boolean
reversescale.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `cmax` will correspond to the first color.

showscale.name: boolean
showscale.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

coloraxis.name: subplotid
coloraxis.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

opacity.name: number
opacity.docString: Sets the opacity of the surface. Please note that in the case of using high `opacity` values for example a value greater than or equal to 0.5 on two surfaces (and 0.25 with four surfaces), an overlay of multiple transparent surfaces may not perfectly be sorted in depth by the webgl API. This behavior may be improved in the near future and is subject to change.

flatshading.name: boolean
flatshading.docString: Determines whether or not normal smoothing is applied to the meshes, creating meshes with an angular, low-poly look via flat reflections.

hoverinfo.name: flaglist
hoverinfo.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

showlegend.name: boolean
showlegend.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

xcalendar.name: enumerated
xcalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `x` date data.

ycalendar.name: enumerated
ycalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `y` date data.

zcalendar.name: enumerated
zcalendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use with `z` date data.

scene.name: subplotid
scene.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's 3D coordinate system and a 3D scene. If *scene* (the default value), the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene`. If *scene2*, the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene2`, and so on.

args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x coordinates of the vector field and of the displayed cones.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y coordinates of the vector field and of the displayed cones.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the z coordinates of the vector field and of the displayed cones.

args.name: u
args.docString: Sets the x components of the vector field.

args.name: v
args.docString: Sets the y components of the vector field.

args.name: w
args.docString: Sets the z components of the vector field.

args.name: sizemode
args.docString: Determines whether `sizeref` is set as a *scaled* (i.e unitless) scalar (normalized by the max u/v/w norm in the vector field) or as *absolute* value (in the same units as the vector field).

args.name: sizeref
args.docString: Adjusts the cone size scaling. The size of the cones is determined by their u/v/w norm multiplied a factor and `sizeref`. This factor (computed internally) corresponds to the minimum "time" to travel across two successive x/y/z positions at the average velocity of those two successive positions. All cones in a given trace use the same factor. With `sizemode` set to *scaled*, `sizeref` is unitless, its default value is *0.5* With `sizemode` set to *absolute*, `sizeref` has the same units as the u/v/w vector field, its the default value is half the sample's maximum vector norm.

args.name: anchor
args.docString: Sets the cones' anchor with respect to their x/y/z positions. Note that *cm* denote the cone's center of mass which corresponds to 1/4 from the tail to tip.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the text elements associated with the cones. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variable `norm` Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: showlegend
args.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

args.name: cauto
args.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here u/v/w norm) or the bounds set in `cmin` and `cmax`  Defaults to `false` when `cmin` and `cmax` are set by the user.

args.name: cmax

args.name: autocolorscale

In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

args.name: reversescale

w.docString: Sets the z components of the vector field.

sizemode.name: enumerated
sizemode.docString: Determines whether `sizeref` is set as a *scaled* (i.e unitless) scalar (normalized by the max u/v/w norm in the vector field) or as *absolute* value (in the same units as the vector field).

sizeref.name: number
sizeref.docString: Adjusts the cone size scaling. The size of the cones is determined by their u/v/w norm multiplied a factor and `sizeref`. This factor (computed internally) corresponds to the minimum "time" to travel across two successive x/y/z positions at the average velocity of those two successive positions. All cones in a given trace use the same factor. With `sizemode` set to *scaled*, `sizeref` is unitless, its default value is *0.5* With `sizemode` set to *absolute*, `sizeref` has the same units as the u/v/w vector field, its the default value is half the sample's maximum vector norm.

anchor.name: enumerated
anchor.docString: Sets the cones' anchor with respect to their x/y/z positions. Note that *cm* denote the cone's center of mass which corresponds to 1/4 from the tail to tip.

text.name: string
text.docString: Sets the text elements associated with the cones. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

hovertext.name: string
hovertext.docString: Same as `text`.

hovertemplate.name: string
hovertemplate.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variable `norm` Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

showlegend.name: boolean
showlegend.docString: Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend.

cauto.name: boolean
cauto.docString: Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here u/v/w norm) or the bounds set in `cmin` and `cmax`  Defaults to `false` when `cmin` and `cmax` are set by the user.

cmin.name: number
cmin.docString: Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as u/v/w norm and if set, `cmax` must be set as well.

cmax.name: number
cmax.docString: Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Value should have the same units as u/v/w norm and if set, `cmin` must be set as well.

cmid.name: number
cmid.docString: Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `cmin` and/or `cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Value should have the same units as u/v/w norm. Has no effect when `cauto` is `false`.

colorscale.name: colorscale
colorscale.docString: Sets the colorscale. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)'], [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`cmin` and `cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis.

autocolorscale.name: boolean
autocolorscale.docString: Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `colorscale`. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default  palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed.

reversescale.name: boolean
reversescale.docString: Reverses the color mapping if true. If true, `cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `cmax` will correspond to the first color.

showscale.name: boolean
showscale.docString: Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace.

coloraxis.name: subplotid
coloraxis.docString: Sets a reference to a shared color axis. References to these shared color axes are *coloraxis*, *coloraxis2*, *coloraxis3*, etc. Settings for these shared color axes are set in the layout, under `layout.coloraxis`, `layout.coloraxis2`, etc. Note that multiple color scales can be linked to the same color axis.

opacity.name: number
opacity.docString: Sets the opacity of the surface. Please note that in the case of using high `opacity` values for example a value greater than or equal to 0.5 on two surfaces (and 0.25 with four surfaces), an overlay of multiple transparent surfaces may not perfectly be sorted in depth by the webgl API. This behavior may be improved in the near future and is subject to change.

hoverinfo.name: flaglist
hoverinfo.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

scene.name: subplotid
scene.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's 3D coordinate system and a 3D scene. If *scene* (the default value), the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene`. If *scene2*, the (x,y,z) coordinates refer to `layout.scene2`, and so on.

idssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ids .

customdatasrc.name: string
customdatasrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  customdata .

metasrc.name: string
metasrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  meta .

xsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  x .

ysrc.name: string
ysrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  y .

zsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  z .

usrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  u .

vsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  v .

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible).

args.name: legendgroup
args.docString: Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items.

args.name: name
args.docString: Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover.

args.name: uid
args.docString: Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions.

args.name: ids
args.docString: Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type.

args.name: customdata
args.docString: Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements

args.name: meta
args.docString: Assigns extra meta information associated with this trace that can be used in various text attributes. Attributes such as trace `name`, graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. To access the trace `meta` values in an attribute in the same trace, simply use `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` item in question. To access trace `meta` in layout attributes, use `%{data[n[.meta[i]}` where `i` is the index or key of the `meta` and `n` is the trace index.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x coordinates of the vector field.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y coordinates of the vector field.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the z coordinates of the vector field.

args.name: u
args.docString: Sets the x components of the vector field.

args.name: v
args.docString: Sets the y components of the vector field.

args.name: w
args.docString: Sets the z components of the vector field.

args.name: maxdisplayed
args.docString: The maximum number of displayed segments in a streamtube.

args.name: sizeref
args.docString: The scaling factor for the streamtubes. The default is 1, which avoids two max divergence tubes from touching at adjacent starting positions.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets a text element associated with this trace. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag, this text element will be seen in all hover labels. Note that streamtube traces do not support array `text` values.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Same as `text`.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variables `tubex`, `tubey`, `tubez`, `tubeu`, `tubev`, `tubew`, `norm` and `divergence`. Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.docString: An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays.

Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves.

args.name: lon
args.docString: Sets the longitude coordinates (in degrees East).

args.name: lat
args.docString: Sets the latitude coordinates (in degrees North).

args.name: locations
args.docString: Sets the coordinates via location IDs or names. Coordinates correspond to the centroid of each location given. See `locationmode` for more info.

args.name: locationmode
args.docString: Determines the set of locations used to match entries in `locations` to regions on the map. Values *ISO-3*, *USA-states*, *country names* correspond to features on the base map and value *geojson-id* corresponds to features from a custom GeoJSON linked to the `geojson` attribute.

args.name: geojson
args.docString: Sets optional GeoJSON data associated with this trace. If not given, the features on the base map are used when `locations` is set. It can be set as a valid GeoJSON object or as a URL string. Note that we only accept GeoJSONs of type *FeatureCollection* or *Feature* with geometries of type *Polygon* or *MultiPolygon*.

args.name: featureidkey
args.docString: Sets the key in GeoJSON features which is used as id to match the items included in the `locations` array. Only has an effect when `geojson` is set. Support nested property, for example *properties.name*.

args.name: mode
args.docString: Determines the drawing mode for this scatter trace. If the provided `mode` includes *text* then the `text` elements appear at the coordinates. Otherwise, the `text` elements appear on hover. If there are less than 20 points and the trace is not stacked then the default is *lines+markers*. Otherwise, *lines*.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets text elements associated with each (lon,lat) pair or item in `locations`. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (lon,lat) or `locations` coordinates. If trace `hoverinfo` contains a *text* flag and *hovertext* is not set, these elements will be seen in the hover labels.

args.name: texttemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information text that appear on points. Note that this will override `textinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. Every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. variables `lat`, `lon`, `location` and `text`.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Sets hover text elements associated with each (lon,lat) pair or item in `locations`. If a single string, the same string appears over all the data points. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's (lon,lat) or `locations` coordinates. To be seen, trace `hoverinfo` must contain a *text* flag.

args.name: textfont
args.docString: Sets the text font.

args.name: textposition
args.docString: Sets the positions of the `text` elements with respects to the (x,y) coordinates.

args.name: connectgaps
args.docString: Determines whether or not gaps (i.e. {nan} or missing values) in the provided data arrays are connected.

args.name: fill
args.docString: Sets the area to fill with a solid color. Use with `fillcolor` if not *none*. *toself* connects the endpoints of the trace (or each segment of the trace if it has gaps) into a closed shape.

args.name: fillcolor
args.docString: Sets the fill color. Defaults to a half-transparent variant of the line color, marker color, or marker line color, whichever is available.

args.name: hoverinfo
args.docString: Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired.

args.name: hovertemplate
args.docString: Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format for details on the formatting syntax. Dates are formatted using d3-time-format's syntax %{variable|d3-time-format}, for example "Day: %{2019-01-01|%A}". https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format for details on the date formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plotly.com/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available.  Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`.

args.name: geo
args.docString: Sets a reference between this trace's geospatial coordinates and a geographic map. If *geo* (the default value), the geospatial coordinates refer to `layout.geo`. If *geo2*, the geospatial coordinates refer to `layout.geo2`, and so on.
