yaxes.docString: Used with `yaxes` when the x and y axes are shared across columns and rows. Each entry should be an y axis id like *y*, *y2*, etc., or ** to not put a y axis in that row. Entries other than ** must be unique. Ignored if `subplots` is present. If missing but `xaxes` is present, will generate consecutive IDs.

pattern.name: enumerated
pattern.docString: If no `subplots`, `xaxes`, or `yaxes` are given but we do have `rows` and `columns`, we can generate defaults using consecutive axis IDs, in two ways: *coupled* gives one x axis per column and one y axis per row. *independent* uses a new xy pair for each cell, left-to-right across each row then iterating rows according to `roworder`.

xgap.name: number
xgap.docString: Horizontal space between grid cells, expressed as a fraction of the total width available to one cell. Defaults to 0.1 for coupled-axes grids and 0.2 for independent grids.

ygap.name: number
ygap.docString: Vertical space between grid cells, expressed as a fraction of the total height available to one cell. Defaults to 0.1 for coupled-axes grids and 0.3 for independent grids.

xside.name: enumerated
xside.docString: Sets where the x axis labels and titles go. *bottom* means the very bottom of the grid. *bottom plot* is the lowest plot that each x axis is used in. *top* and *top plot* are similar.

yside.name: enumerated
yside.docString: Sets where the y axis labels and titles go. *left* means the very left edge of the grid. *left plot* is the leftmost plot that each y axis is used in. *right* and *right plot* are similar.

args.name: visible
args.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

args.name: type
args.docString: Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question.

args.name: autotypenumbers
args.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

args.name: autorange
args.docString: Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*.

args.name: rangemode
args.docString: If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes.

args.name: range
args.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: fixedrange
args.docString: Determines whether or not this axis is zoom-able. If true, then zoom is disabled.

args.name: scaleanchor
args.docString: If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis changes together with the range of the corresponding axis such that the scale of pixels per unit is in a constant ratio. Both axes are still zoomable, but when you zoom one, the other will zoom the same amount, keeping a fixed midpoint. `constrain` and `constraintoward` determine how we enforce the constraint. You can chain these, ie `yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis2: {scaleanchor: *y*}` but you can only link axes of the same `type`. The linked axis can have the opposite letter (to constrain the aspect ratio) or the same letter (to match scales across subplots). Loops (`yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis: {scaleanchor: *y*}` or longer) are redundant and the last constraint encountered will be ignored to avoid possible inconsistent constraints via `scaleratio`. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden.

args.name: scaleratio
args.docString: If this axis is linked to another by `scaleanchor`, this determines the pixel to unit scale ratio. For example, if this value is 10, then every unit on this axis spans 10 times the number of pixels as a unit on the linked axis. Use this for example to create an elevation profile where the vertical scale is exaggerated a fixed amount with respect to the horizontal.

args.name: constrain
args.docString: If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines how that happens: by increasing the *range*, or by decreasing the *domain*. Default is *domain* for axes containing image traces, *range* otherwise.

args.name: constraintoward
args.docString: If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines which direction we push the originally specified plot area. Options are *left*, *center* (default), and *right* for x axes, and *top*, *middle* (default), and *bottom* for y axes.

args.name: matches
args.docString: If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis will match the range of the corresponding axis in data-coordinates space. Moreover, matching axes share auto-range values, category lists and histogram auto-bins. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden. Moreover, note that matching axes must have the same `type`.

args.name: tickmode
args.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

args.name: nticks
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

args.name: tick0
args.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: dtick
args.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

args.name: tickvals
args.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

args.name: ticktext
args.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

args.name: ticks
args.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

args.name: tickson
args.docString: Determines where ticks and grid lines are drawn with respect to their corresponding tick labels. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *category* or *multicategory*. When set to *boundaries*, ticks and grid lines are drawn half a category to the left/bottom of labels.

args.name: ticklabelmode
args.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn with respect to their corresponding ticks and grid lines. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *date* When set to *period*, tick labels are drawn in the middle of the period between ticks.

args.name: ticklabelposition
args.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn with respect to the axis Please note that top or bottom has no effect on x axes or when `ticklabelmode` is set to *period*. Similarly left or right has no effect on y axes or when `ticklabelmode` is set to *period*. Has no effect on *multicategory* axes or when `tickson` is set to *boundaries*. When used on axes linked by `matches` or `scaleanchor`, no extra padding for inside labels would be added by autorange, so that the scales could match.

args.name: mirror
args.docString: Determines if the axis lines or/and ticks are mirrored to the opposite side of the plotting area. If *true*, the axis lines are mirrored. If *ticks*, the axis lines and ticks are mirrored. If *false*, mirroring is disable. If *all*, axis lines are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. If *allticks*, axis lines and ticks are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots.

args.name: ticklen
args.docString: Sets the tick length (in px).

args.name: tickwidth
args.docString: Sets the tick width (in px).

args.name: tickcolor
args.docString: Sets the tick color.

args.name: showticklabels
args.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

args.name: automargin
args.docString: Determines whether long tick labels automatically grow the figure margins.

args.name: showspikes
args.docString: Determines whether or not spikes (aka droplines) are drawn for this axis. Note: This only takes affect when hovermode = closest

args.name: spikecolor
args.docString: Sets the spike color. If undefined, will use the series color

args.name: spikethickness
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

args.name: spikedash
args.docString: Sets the dash style of lines. Set to a dash type string (*solid*, *dot*, *dash*, *longdash*, *dashdot*, or *longdashdot*) or a dash length list in px (eg *5px,10px,2px,2px*).

args.name: spikemode
args.docString: Determines the drawing mode for the spike line If *toaxis*, the line is drawn from the data point to the axis the  series is plotted on. If *across*, the line is drawn across the entire plot area, and supercedes *toaxis*. If *marker*, then a marker dot is drawn on the axis the series is plotted on

args.name: spikesnap
args.docString: Determines whether spikelines are stuck to the cursor or to the closest datapoints.

args.name: tickfont
args.docString: Sets the tick font.

args.name: tickangle
args.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

args.name: tickprefix
args.docString: Sets a tick label prefix.

args.name: showtickprefix
args.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

args.name: ticksuffix
args.docString: Sets a tick label suffix.

args.name: showticksuffix
args.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

args.name: showexponent
args.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

args.name: exponentformat
args.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

args.name: minexponent
args.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

args.name: separatethousands
args.docString: If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated

args.name: tickformat
args.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: hoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: showline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

args.name: linecolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: linewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

args.name: showgrid
args.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

args.name: gridcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

args.name: gridwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

args.name: zeroline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines.

args.name: zerolinecolor
args.docString: Sets the line color of the zero line.

args.name: zerolinewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

args.name: showdividers
args.docString: Determines whether or not a dividers are drawn between the category levels of this axis. Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

args.name: dividercolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

args.name: dividerwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

args.name: anchor
args.docString: If set to an opposite-letter axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), this axis is bound to the corresponding opposite-letter axis. If set to *free*, this axis' position is determined by `position`.

args.name: side
args.docString: Determines whether a x (y) axis is positioned at the *bottom* (*left*) or *top* (*right*) of the plotting area.

args.name: overlaying
args.docString: If set a same-letter axis id, this axis is overlaid on top of the corresponding same-letter axis, with traces and axes visible for both axes. If *false*, this axis does not overlay any same-letter axes. In this case, for axes with overlapping domains only the highest-numbered axis will be visible.

args.name: layer
args.docString: Sets the layer on which this axis is displayed. If *above traces*, this axis is displayed above all the subplot's traces If *below traces*, this axis is displayed below all the subplot's traces, but above the grid lines. Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis.

args.name: domain
args.docString: Sets the domain of this axis (in plot fraction).

args.name: position
args.docString: Sets the position of this axis in the plotting space (in normalized coordinates). Only has an effect if `anchor` is set to *free*.

args.name: categoryorder
args.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

args.name: categoryarray
args.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `range`, `autorange`, and `title` if in `editable: true` configuration. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

args.name: calendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

args.name: tickvalssrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

args.name: ticktextsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

args.name: categoryarraysrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

visible.name: boolean
visible.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

type.name: enumerated
type.docString: Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question.

autotypenumbers.name: enumerated
autotypenumbers.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

autorange.name: enumerated
autorange.docString: Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*.

rangemode.name: enumerated
rangemode.docString: If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes.

range.name: info_array
range.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

fixedrange.name: boolean
fixedrange.docString: Determines whether or not this axis is zoom-able. If true, then zoom is disabled.

scaleanchor.name: enumerated
scaleanchor.docString: If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis changes together with the range of the corresponding axis such that the scale of pixels per unit is in a constant ratio. Both axes are still zoomable, but when you zoom one, the other will zoom the same amount, keeping a fixed midpoint. `constrain` and `constraintoward` determine how we enforce the constraint. You can chain these, ie `yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis2: {scaleanchor: *y*}` but you can only link axes of the same `type`. The linked axis can have the opposite letter (to constrain the aspect ratio) or the same letter (to match scales across subplots). Loops (`yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis: {scaleanchor: *y*}` or longer) are redundant and the last constraint encountered will be ignored to avoid possible inconsistent constraints via `scaleratio`. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden.

scaleratio.name: number
scaleratio.docString: If this axis is linked to another by `scaleanchor`, this determines the pixel to unit scale ratio. For example, if this value is 10, then every unit on this axis spans 10 times the number of pixels as a unit on the linked axis. Use this for example to create an elevation profile where the vertical scale is exaggerated a fixed amount with respect to the horizontal.

constrain.name: enumerated
constrain.docString: If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines how that happens: by increasing the *range*, or by decreasing the *domain*. Default is *domain* for axes containing image traces, *range* otherwise.

constraintoward.name: enumerated
constraintoward.docString: If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines which direction we push the originally specified plot area. Options are *left*, *center* (default), and *right* for x axes, and *top*, *middle* (default), and *bottom* for y axes.

matches.name: enumerated
matches.docString: If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis will match the range of the corresponding axis in data-coordinates space. Moreover, matching axes share auto-range values, category lists and histogram auto-bins. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden. Moreover, note that matching axes must have the same `type`.

tickmode.name: enumerated
tickmode.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

nticks.name: integer
nticks.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

tick0.name: any
tick0.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

dtick.name: any
dtick.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

tickvals.name: data_array
tickvals.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

ticktext.name: data_array
ticktext.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

ticks.name: enumerated
ticks.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

tickson.name: enumerated
tickson.docString: Determines where ticks and grid lines are drawn with respect to their corresponding tick labels. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *category* or *multicategory*. When set to *boundaries*, ticks and grid lines are drawn half a category to the left/bottom of labels.

ticklabelmode.name: enumerated
ticklabelmode.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn with respect to their corresponding ticks and grid lines. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *date* When set to *period*, tick labels are drawn in the middle of the period between ticks.

ticklabelposition.name: enumerated
ticklabelposition.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn with respect to the axis Please note that top or bottom has no effect on x axes or when `ticklabelmode` is set to *period*. Similarly left or right has no effect on y axes or when `ticklabelmode` is set to *period*. Has no effect on *multicategory* axes or when `tickson` is set to *boundaries*. When used on axes linked by `matches` or `scaleanchor`, no extra padding for inside labels would be added by autorange, so that the scales could match.

mirror.name: enumerated
mirror.docString: Determines if the axis lines or/and ticks are mirrored to the opposite side of the plotting area. If *true*, the axis lines are mirrored. If *ticks*, the axis lines and ticks are mirrored. If *false*, mirroring is disable. If *all*, axis lines are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. If *allticks*, axis lines and ticks are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots.

showticklabels.name: boolean
showticklabels.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

automargin.name: boolean
automargin.docString: Determines whether long tick labels automatically grow the figure margins.

showspikes.name: boolean
showspikes.docString: Determines whether or not spikes (aka droplines) are drawn for this axis. Note: This only takes affect when hovermode = closest

spikecolor.name: color
spikecolor.docString: Sets the spike color. If undefined, will use the series color

spikethickness.name: number
spikethickness.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

spikedash.name: string
spikedash.docString: Sets the dash style of lines. Set to a dash type string (*solid*, *dot*, *dash*, *longdash*, *dashdot*, or *longdashdot*) or a dash length list in px (eg *5px,10px,2px,2px*).

spikemode.name: flaglist
spikemode.docString: Determines the drawing mode for the spike line If *toaxis*, the line is drawn from the data point to the axis the  series is plotted on. If *across*, the line is drawn across the entire plot area, and supercedes *toaxis*. If *marker*, then a marker dot is drawn on the axis the series is plotted on

spikesnap.name: enumerated
spikesnap.docString: Determines whether spikelines are stuck to the cursor or to the closest datapoints.

tickangle.name: angle
tickangle.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

showtickprefix.name: enumerated
showtickprefix.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

showticksuffix.name: enumerated
showticksuffix.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

showexponent.name: enumerated
showexponent.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

exponentformat.name: enumerated
exponentformat.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

minexponent.name: number
minexponent.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

tickformat.name: string
tickformat.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

hoverformat.name: string
hoverformat.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

showline.name: boolean
showline.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

linewidth.name: number
linewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

showgrid.name: boolean
showgrid.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

gridcolor.name: color
gridcolor.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

gridwidth.name: number
gridwidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

zeroline.name: boolean
zeroline.docString: Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines.

zerolinecolor.name: color
zerolinecolor.docString: Sets the line color of the zero line.

zerolinewidth.name: number
zerolinewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

showdividers.name: boolean
showdividers.docString: Determines whether or not a dividers are drawn between the category levels of this axis. Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

dividercolor.name: color
dividercolor.docString: Sets the color of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

dividerwidth.name: number
dividerwidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

anchor.name: enumerated
anchor.docString: If set to an opposite-letter axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), this axis is bound to the corresponding opposite-letter axis. If set to *free*, this axis' position is determined by `position`.

side.name: enumerated
side.docString: Determines whether a x (y) axis is positioned at the *bottom* (*left*) or *top* (*right*) of the plotting area.

overlaying.name: enumerated
overlaying.docString: If set a same-letter axis id, this axis is overlaid on top of the corresponding same-letter axis, with traces and axes visible for both axes. If *false*, this axis does not overlay any same-letter axes. In this case, for axes with overlapping domains only the highest-numbered axis will be visible.

layer.name: enumerated
layer.docString: Sets the layer on which this axis is displayed. If *above traces*, this axis is displayed above all the subplot's traces If *below traces*, this axis is displayed below all the subplot's traces, but above the grid lines. Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis.

domain.name: info_array
domain.docString: Sets the domain of this axis (in plot fraction).

position.name: number
position.docString: Sets the position of this axis in the plotting space (in normalized coordinates). Only has an effect if `anchor` is set to *free*.

categoryorder.name: enumerated
categoryorder.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

categoryarray.name: data_array
categoryarray.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `range`, `autorange`, and `title` if in `editable: true` configuration. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

calendar.name: enumerated
calendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

tickvalssrc.name: string
tickvalssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

ticktextsrc.name: string
ticktextsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

categoryarraysrc.name: string
categoryarraysrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

args.name: visible
args.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

args.name: type
args.docString: Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question.

args.name: autotypenumbers
args.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

args.name: autorange
args.docString: Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*.

args.name: rangemode
args.docString: If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes.

args.name: range
args.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: fixedrange
args.docString: Determines whether or not this axis is zoom-able. If true, then zoom is disabled.

args.name: scaleanchor
args.docString: If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis changes together with the range of the corresponding axis such that the scale of pixels per unit is in a constant ratio. Both axes are still zoomable, but when you zoom one, the other will zoom the same amount, keeping a fixed midpoint. `constrain` and `constraintoward` determine how we enforce the constraint. You can chain these, ie `yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis2: {scaleanchor: *y*}` but you can only link axes of the same `type`. The linked axis can have the opposite letter (to constrain the aspect ratio) or the same letter (to match scales across subplots). Loops (`yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis: {scaleanchor: *y*}` or longer) are redundant and the last constraint encountered will be ignored to avoid possible inconsistent constraints via `scaleratio`. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden.

args.name: scaleratio
args.docString: If this axis is linked to another by `scaleanchor`, this determines the pixel to unit scale ratio. For example, if this value is 10, then every unit on this axis spans 10 times the number of pixels as a unit on the linked axis. Use this for example to create an elevation profile where the vertical scale is exaggerated a fixed amount with respect to the horizontal.

args.name: constrain
args.docString: If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines how that happens: by increasing the *range*, or by decreasing the *domain*. Default is *domain* for axes containing image traces, *range* otherwise.

args.name: constraintoward
args.docString: If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines which direction we push the originally specified plot area. Options are *left*, *center* (default), and *right* for x axes, and *top*, *middle* (default), and *bottom* for y axes.

args.name: matches
args.docString: If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis will match the range of the corresponding axis in data-coordinates space. Moreover, matching axes share auto-range values, category lists and histogram auto-bins. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden. Moreover, note that matching axes must have the same `type`.

args.name: tickmode
args.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

args.name: nticks
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

args.name: tick0
args.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: dtick
args.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

args.name: tickvals
args.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

args.name: ticktext
args.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

args.name: ticks
args.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

args.name: tickson
args.docString: Determines where ticks and grid lines are drawn with respect to their corresponding tick labels. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *category* or *multicategory*. When set to *boundaries*, ticks and grid lines are drawn half a category to the left/bottom of labels.

args.name: ticklabelmode
args.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn with respect to their corresponding ticks and grid lines. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *date* When set to *period*, tick labels are drawn in the middle of the period between ticks.

args.name: ticklabelposition
args.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn with respect to the axis Please note that top or bottom has no effect on x axes or when `ticklabelmode` is set to *period*. Similarly left or right has no effect on y axes or when `ticklabelmode` is set to *period*. Has no effect on *multicategory* axes or when `tickson` is set to *boundaries*. When used on axes linked by `matches` or `scaleanchor`, no extra padding for inside labels would be added by autorange, so that the scales could match.

args.name: mirror
args.docString: Determines if the axis lines or/and ticks are mirrored to the opposite side of the plotting area. If *true*, the axis lines are mirrored. If *ticks*, the axis lines and ticks are mirrored. If *false*, mirroring is disable. If *all*, axis lines are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. If *allticks*, axis lines and ticks are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots.

args.name: ticklen
args.docString: Sets the tick length (in px).

args.name: tickwidth
args.docString: Sets the tick width (in px).

args.name: tickcolor
args.docString: Sets the tick color.

args.name: showticklabels
args.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

args.name: automargin
args.docString: Determines whether long tick labels automatically grow the figure margins.

args.name: showspikes
args.docString: Determines whether or not spikes (aka droplines) are drawn for this axis. Note: This only takes affect when hovermode = closest

args.name: spikecolor
args.docString: Sets the spike color. If undefined, will use the series color

args.name: spikethickness
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

args.name: spikedash
args.docString: Sets the dash style of lines. Set to a dash type string (*solid*, *dot*, *dash*, *longdash*, *dashdot*, or *longdashdot*) or a dash length list in px (eg *5px,10px,2px,2px*).

args.name: spikemode
args.docString: Determines the drawing mode for the spike line If *toaxis*, the line is drawn from the data point to the axis the  series is plotted on. If *across*, the line is drawn across the entire plot area, and supercedes *toaxis*. If *marker*, then a marker dot is drawn on the axis the series is plotted on

args.name: spikesnap
args.docString: Determines whether spikelines are stuck to the cursor or to the closest datapoints.

args.name: tickfont
args.docString: Sets the tick font.

args.name: tickangle
args.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

args.name: tickprefix
args.docString: Sets a tick label prefix.

args.name: showtickprefix
args.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

args.name: ticksuffix
args.docString: Sets a tick label suffix.

args.name: showticksuffix
args.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

args.name: showexponent
args.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

args.name: exponentformat
args.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

args.name: minexponent
args.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

args.name: separatethousands
args.docString: If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated

args.name: tickformat
args.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: hoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: showline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

args.name: linecolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: linewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

args.name: showgrid
args.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

args.name: gridcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

args.name: gridwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

args.name: zeroline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines.

args.name: zerolinecolor
args.docString: Sets the line color of the zero line.

args.name: zerolinewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

args.name: showdividers
args.docString: Determines whether or not a dividers are drawn between the category levels of this axis. Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

args.name: dividercolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

args.name: dividerwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

args.name: anchor
args.docString: If set to an opposite-letter axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), this axis is bound to the corresponding opposite-letter axis. If set to *free*, this axis' position is determined by `position`.

args.name: side
args.docString: Determines whether a x (y) axis is positioned at the *bottom* (*left*) or *top* (*right*) of the plotting area.

args.name: overlaying
args.docString: If set a same-letter axis id, this axis is overlaid on top of the corresponding same-letter axis, with traces and axes visible for both axes. If *false*, this axis does not overlay any same-letter axes. In this case, for axes with overlapping domains only the highest-numbered axis will be visible.

args.name: layer
args.docString: Sets the layer on which this axis is displayed. If *above traces*, this axis is displayed above all the subplot's traces If *below traces*, this axis is displayed below all the subplot's traces, but above the grid lines. Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis.

args.name: domain
args.docString: Sets the domain of this axis (in plot fraction).

args.name: position
args.docString: Sets the position of this axis in the plotting space (in normalized coordinates). Only has an effect if `anchor` is set to *free*.

args.name: categoryorder
args.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

args.name: categoryarray
args.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `range`, `autorange`, and `title` if in `editable: true` configuration. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

args.name: calendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

args.name: tickvalssrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

args.name: ticktextsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

args.name: categoryarraysrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

visible.name: boolean
visible.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

type.name: enumerated
type.docString: Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question.

autotypenumbers.name: enumerated
autotypenumbers.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

autorange.name: enumerated
autorange.docString: Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*.

rangemode.name: enumerated
rangemode.docString: If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes.

range.name: info_array
range.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

fixedrange.name: boolean
fixedrange.docString: Determines whether or not this axis is zoom-able. If true, then zoom is disabled.

scaleanchor.name: enumerated
scaleanchor.docString: If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis changes together with the range of the corresponding axis such that the scale of pixels per unit is in a constant ratio. Both axes are still zoomable, but when you zoom one, the other will zoom the same amount, keeping a fixed midpoint. `constrain` and `constraintoward` determine how we enforce the constraint. You can chain these, ie `yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis2: {scaleanchor: *y*}` but you can only link axes of the same `type`. The linked axis can have the opposite letter (to constrain the aspect ratio) or the same letter (to match scales across subplots). Loops (`yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis: {scaleanchor: *y*}` or longer) are redundant and the last constraint encountered will be ignored to avoid possible inconsistent constraints via `scaleratio`. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden.

scaleratio.name: number
scaleratio.docString: If this axis is linked to another by `scaleanchor`, this determines the pixel to unit scale ratio. For example, if this value is 10, then every unit on this axis spans 10 times the number of pixels as a unit on the linked axis. Use this for example to create an elevation profile where the vertical scale is exaggerated a fixed amount with respect to the horizontal.

constrain.name: enumerated
constrain.docString: If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines how that happens: by increasing the *range*, or by decreasing the *domain*. Default is *domain* for axes containing image traces, *range* otherwise.

constraintoward.name: enumerated
constraintoward.docString: If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines which direction we push the originally specified plot area. Options are *left*, *center* (default), and *right* for x axes, and *top*, *middle* (default), and *bottom* for y axes.

matches.name: enumerated
matches.docString: If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis will match the range of the corresponding axis in data-coordinates space. Moreover, matching axes share auto-range values, category lists and histogram auto-bins. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden. Moreover, note that matching axes must have the same `type`.

tickmode.name: enumerated
tickmode.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

nticks.name: integer
nticks.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

tick0.name: any
tick0.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

dtick.name: any
dtick.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

tickvals.name: data_array
tickvals.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

ticktext.name: data_array
ticktext.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

ticks.name: enumerated
ticks.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

tickson.name: enumerated
tickson.docString: Determines where ticks and grid lines are drawn with respect to their corresponding tick labels. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *category* or *multicategory*. When set to *boundaries*, ticks and grid lines are drawn half a category to the left/bottom of labels.

ticklabelmode.name: enumerated
ticklabelmode.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn with respect to their corresponding ticks and grid lines. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *date* When set to *period*, tick labels are drawn in the middle of the period between ticks.

ticklabelposition.name: enumerated
ticklabelposition.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn with respect to the axis Please note that top or bottom has no effect on x axes or when `ticklabelmode` is set to *period*. Similarly left or right has no effect on y axes or when `ticklabelmode` is set to *period*. Has no effect on *multicategory* axes or when `tickson` is set to *boundaries*. When used on axes linked by `matches` or `scaleanchor`, no extra padding for inside labels would be added by autorange, so that the scales could match.

mirror.name: enumerated
mirror.docString: Determines if the axis lines or/and ticks are mirrored to the opposite side of the plotting area. If *true*, the axis lines are mirrored. If *ticks*, the axis lines and ticks are mirrored. If *false*, mirroring is disable. If *all*, axis lines are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. If *allticks*, axis lines and ticks are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots.

showticklabels.name: boolean
showticklabels.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

automargin.name: boolean
automargin.docString: Determines whether long tick labels automatically grow the figure margins.

showspikes.name: boolean
showspikes.docString: Determines whether or not spikes (aka droplines) are drawn for this axis. Note: This only takes affect when hovermode = closest

spikecolor.name: color
spikecolor.docString: Sets the spike color. If undefined, will use the series color

spikethickness.name: number
spikethickness.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

spikedash.name: string
spikedash.docString: Sets the dash style of lines. Set to a dash type string (*solid*, *dot*, *dash*, *longdash*, *dashdot*, or *longdashdot*) or a dash length list in px (eg *5px,10px,2px,2px*).

spikemode.name: flaglist
spikemode.docString: Determines the drawing mode for the spike line If *toaxis*, the line is drawn from the data point to the axis the  series is plotted on. If *across*, the line is drawn across the entire plot area, and supercedes *toaxis*. If *marker*, then a marker dot is drawn on the axis the series is plotted on

spikesnap.name: enumerated
spikesnap.docString: Determines whether spikelines are stuck to the cursor or to the closest datapoints.

tickangle.name: angle
tickangle.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

showtickprefix.name: enumerated
showtickprefix.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

showticksuffix.name: enumerated
showticksuffix.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

showexponent.name: enumerated
showexponent.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

exponentformat.name: enumerated
exponentformat.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

minexponent.name: number
minexponent.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

tickformat.name: string
tickformat.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

hoverformat.name: string
hoverformat.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

showline.name: boolean
showline.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

linewidth.name: number
linewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

showgrid.name: boolean
showgrid.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

gridcolor.name: color
gridcolor.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

gridwidth.name: number
gridwidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

zeroline.name: boolean
zeroline.docString: Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines.

zerolinecolor.name: color
zerolinecolor.docString: Sets the line color of the zero line.

zerolinewidth.name: number
zerolinewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

showdividers.name: boolean
showdividers.docString: Determines whether or not a dividers are drawn between the category levels of this axis. Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

dividercolor.name: color
dividercolor.docString: Sets the color of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

dividerwidth.name: number
dividerwidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes.

anchor.name: enumerated
anchor.docString: If set to an opposite-letter axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), this axis is bound to the corresponding opposite-letter axis. If set to *free*, this axis' position is determined by `position`.

side.name: enumerated
side.docString: Determines whether a x (y) axis is positioned at the *bottom* (*left*) or *top* (*right*) of the plotting area.

overlaying.name: enumerated
overlaying.docString: If set a same-letter axis id, this axis is overlaid on top of the corresponding same-letter axis, with traces and axes visible for both axes. If *false*, this axis does not overlay any same-letter axes. In this case, for axes with overlapping domains only the highest-numbered axis will be visible.

layer.name: enumerated
layer.docString: Sets the layer on which this axis is displayed. If *above traces*, this axis is displayed above all the subplot's traces If *below traces*, this axis is displayed below all the subplot's traces, but above the grid lines. Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis.

domain.name: info_array
domain.docString: Sets the domain of this axis (in plot fraction).

position.name: number
position.docString: Sets the position of this axis in the plotting space (in normalized coordinates). Only has an effect if `anchor` is set to *free*.

categoryorder.name: enumerated
categoryorder.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

categoryarray.name: data_array
categoryarray.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `range`, `autorange`, and `title` if in `editable: true` configuration. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

calendar.name: enumerated
calendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

tickvalssrc.name: string
tickvalssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

ticktextsrc.name: string
ticktextsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

categoryarraysrc.name: string
categoryarraysrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

args.name: bgcolor
args.docString: Set the background color of the subplot

args.name: sum
args.docString: The number each triplet should sum to, and the maximum range of each axis

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `min` and `title`, if not overridden in the individual axes. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

bgcolor.name: color
bgcolor.docString: Set the background color of the subplot

sum.name: number
sum.docString: The number each triplet should sum to, and the maximum range of each axis

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `min` and `title`, if not overridden in the individual axes. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

args.name: aspectmode
args.docString: If *cube*, this scene's axes are drawn as a cube, regardless of the axes' ranges. If *data*, this scene's axes are drawn in proportion with the axes' ranges. If *manual*, this scene's axes are drawn in proportion with the input of *aspectratio* (the default behavior if *aspectratio* is provided). If *auto*, this scene's axes are drawn using the results of *data* except when one axis is more than four times the size of the two others, where in that case the results of *cube* are used.

args.name: aspectratio
args.docString: Sets this scene's axis aspectratio.

args.name: dragmode
args.docString: Determines the mode of drag interactions for this scene.

args.name: hovermode
args.docString: Determines the mode of hover interactions for this scene.

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in camera attributes. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

aspectmode.name: enumerated
aspectmode.docString: If *cube*, this scene's axes are drawn as a cube, regardless of the axes' ranges. If *data*, this scene's axes are drawn in proportion with the axes' ranges. If *manual*, this scene's axes are drawn in proportion with the input of *aspectratio* (the default behavior if *aspectratio* is provided). If *auto*, this scene's axes are drawn using the results of *data* except when one axis is more than four times the size of the two others, where in that case the results of *cube* are used.

dragmode.name: enumerated
dragmode.docString: Determines the mode of drag interactions for this scene.

hovermode.name: enumerated
hovermode.docString: Determines the mode of hover interactions for this scene.

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in camera attributes. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

args.name: fitbounds
args.docString: Determines if this subplot's view settings are auto-computed to fit trace data. On scoped maps, setting `fitbounds` leads to `center.lon` and `center.lat` getting auto-filled. On maps with a non-clipped projection, setting `fitbounds` leads to `center.lon`, `center.lat`, and `projection.rotation.lon` getting auto-filled. On maps with a clipped projection, setting `fitbounds` leads to `center.lon`, `center.lat`, `projection.rotation.lon`, `projection.rotation.lat`, `lonaxis.range` and `lonaxis.range` getting auto-filled. If *locations*, only the trace's visible locations are considered in the `fitbounds` computations. If *geojson*, the entire trace input `geojson` (if provided) is considered in the `fitbounds` computations, Defaults to *false*.

args.name: resolution
args.docString: Sets the resolution of the base layers. The values have units of km/mm e.g. 110 corresponds to a scale ratio of 1:110,000,000.

args.name: scope
args.docString: Set the scope of the map.

args.name: visible
args.docString: Sets the default visibility of the base layers.

args.name: showcoastlines
args.docString: Sets whether or not the coastlines are drawn.

args.name: coastlinecolor
args.docString: Sets the coastline color.

args.name: coastlinewidth
args.docString: Sets the coastline stroke width (in px).

args.name: showland
args.docString: Sets whether or not land masses are filled in color.

args.name: landcolor
args.docString: Sets the land mass color.

args.name: showocean
args.docString: Sets whether or not oceans are filled in color.

args.name: oceancolor
args.docString: Sets the ocean color

args.name: showlakes
args.docString: Sets whether or not lakes are drawn.

args.name: lakecolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the lakes.

args.name: showrivers
args.docString: Sets whether or not rivers are drawn.

args.name: rivercolor
args.docString: Sets color of the rivers.

args.name: riverwidth
args.docString: Sets the stroke width (in px) of the rivers.

args.name: showcountries
args.docString: Sets whether or not country boundaries are drawn.

args.name: countrycolor
args.docString: Sets line color of the country boundaries.

args.name: countrywidth
args.docString: Sets line width (in px) of the country boundaries.

args.name: showsubunits
args.docString: Sets whether or not boundaries of subunits within countries (e.g. states, provinces) are drawn.

args.name: subunitcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the subunits boundaries.

args.name: subunitwidth
args.docString: Sets the stroke width (in px) of the subunits boundaries.

args.name: showframe
args.docString: Sets whether or not a frame is drawn around the map.

args.name: framecolor
args.docString: Sets the color the frame.

args.name: framewidth
args.docString: Sets the stroke width (in px) of the frame.

args.name: bgcolor
args.docString: Set the background color of the map

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in the view (projection and center). Defaults to `layout.uirevision`.

On maps with a clipped projection, setting `fitbounds` leads to `center.lon`, `center.lat`, `projection.rotation.lon`, `projection.rotation.lat`, `lonaxis.range` and `lonaxis.range` getting auto-filled. If *geojson*, the entire trace input `geojson` (if provided) is considered in the `fitbounds` computations, Defaults to *false*.
