For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

tickvals.name: data_array
tickvals.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

ticktext.name: data_array
ticktext.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

ticks.name: enumerated
ticks.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

showticklabels.name: boolean
showticklabels.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

showtickprefix.name: enumerated
showtickprefix.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

showticksuffix.name: enumerated
showticksuffix.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

showexponent.name: enumerated
showexponent.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

exponentformat.name: enumerated
exponentformat.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

minexponent.name: number
minexponent.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

tickangle.name: angle
tickangle.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

tickformat.name: string
tickformat.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

hoverformat.name: string
hoverformat.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

showline.name: boolean
showline.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

linewidth.name: number
linewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

showgrid.name: boolean
showgrid.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

gridcolor.name: color
gridcolor.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

gridwidth.name: number
gridwidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

layer.name: enumerated
layer.docString: Sets the layer on which this axis is displayed. If *above traces*, this axis is displayed above all the subplot's traces If *below traces*, this axis is displayed below all the subplot's traces, but above the grid lines. Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis.

min.name: number
min.docString: The minimum value visible on this axis. The maximum is determined by the sum minus the minimum values of the other two axes. The full view corresponds to all the minima set to zero.

uirevision.name: any
uirevision.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `min`, and `title` if in `editable: true` configuration. Defaults to `ternary<N>.uirevision`.

tickvalssrc.name: string
tickvalssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

ticktextsrc.name: string
ticktextsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the title of this axis. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated.

args.name: font
args.docString: Sets this axis' title font. Note that the title's font used to be customized by the now deprecated `titlefont` attribute.

text.name: string
text.docString: Sets the title of this axis. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated.

args.name: family
args.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.name: Tickfont

family.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. returns.docString: Sets the tick font.

args.name: enabled
args.docString: Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`.

args.name: dtickrange
args.docString: range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null*

args.name: value
args.docString: string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat*

args.name: name
args.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

args.name: templateitemname
args.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

args.name: up
args.docString: Sets the (x,y,z) components of the 'up' camera vector. This vector determines the up direction of this scene with respect to the page. The default is *{x: 0, y: 0, z: 1}* which means that the z axis points up.

args.name: center
args.docString: Sets the (x,y,z) components of the 'center' camera vector This vector determines the translation (x,y,z) space about the center of this scene. By default, there is no such translation.

args.name: eye
args.docString: Sets the (x,y,z) components of the 'eye' camera vector. This vector determines the view point about the origin of this scene.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the horizontal domain of this scene subplot (in plot fraction).

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the vertical domain of this scene subplot (in plot fraction).

args.name: row
args.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this row in the grid for this scene subplot .

args.name: column
args.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this column in the grid for this scene subplot .

x.name: info_array
x.docString: Sets the horizontal domain of this scene subplot (in plot fraction).

y.name: info_array
y.docString: Sets the vertical domain of this scene subplot (in plot fraction).

row.name: integer
row.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this row in the grid for this scene subplot .

column.name: integer
column.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this column in the grid for this scene subplot .

returns.name: Aspectratio
returns.docString: Sets this scene's axis aspectratio.

args.name: visible
args.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

args.name: showspikes
args.docString: Sets whether or not spikes starting from data points to this axis' wall are shown on hover.

args.name: spikesides
args.docString: Sets whether or not spikes extending from the projection data points to this axis' wall boundaries are shown on hover.

args.name: spikethickness
args.docString: Sets the thickness (in px) of the spikes.

args.name: spikecolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the spikes.

args.name: showbackground
args.docString: Sets whether or not this axis' wall has a background color.

args.name: backgroundcolor
args.docString: Sets the background color of this axis' wall.

args.name: showaxeslabels
args.docString: Sets whether or not this axis is labeled

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

args.name: categoryorder
args.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

args.name: categoryarray
args.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

args.name: type
args.docString: Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question.

args.name: autotypenumbers
args.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

args.name: autorange
args.docString: Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*.

args.name: rangemode
args.docString: If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes.

args.name: range
args.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: tickmode
args.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

args.name: nticks
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

args.name: tick0
args.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: dtick
args.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

args.name: tickvals
args.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

args.name: ticktext
args.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

args.name: ticks
args.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

args.name: mirror
args.docString: Determines if the axis lines or/and ticks are mirrored to the opposite side of the plotting area. If *true*, the axis lines are mirrored. If *ticks*, the axis lines and ticks are mirrored. If *false*, mirroring is disable. If *all*, axis lines are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. If *allticks*, axis lines and ticks are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots.

args.name: ticklen
args.docString: Sets the tick length (in px).

args.name: tickwidth
args.docString: Sets the tick width (in px).

args.name: tickcolor
args.docString: Sets the tick color.

args.name: showticklabels
args.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

args.name: tickfont
args.docString: Sets the tick font.

args.name: tickangle
args.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

args.name: tickprefix
args.docString: Sets a tick label prefix.

args.name: showtickprefix
args.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

args.name: ticksuffix
args.docString: Sets a tick label suffix.

args.name: showticksuffix
args.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

args.name: showexponent
args.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

args.name: exponentformat
args.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

args.name: minexponent
args.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

args.name: separatethousands
args.docString: If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated

args.name: tickformat
args.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: hoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: showline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

args.name: linecolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: linewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

args.name: showgrid
args.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

args.name: gridcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

args.name: gridwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

args.name: zeroline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines.

args.name: zerolinecolor
args.docString: Sets the line color of the zero line.

args.name: zerolinewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

args.name: calendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

args.name: categoryarraysrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

args.name: tickvalssrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

args.name: ticktextsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

visible.name: boolean
visible.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

showspikes.name: boolean
showspikes.docString: Sets whether or not spikes starting from data points to this axis' wall are shown on hover.

spikesides.name: boolean
spikesides.docString: Sets whether or not spikes extending from the projection data points to this axis' wall boundaries are shown on hover.

spikethickness.name: number
spikethickness.docString: Sets the thickness (in px) of the spikes.

spikecolor.name: color
spikecolor.docString: Sets the color of the spikes.

showbackground.name: boolean
showbackground.docString: Sets whether or not this axis' wall has a background color.

backgroundcolor.name: color
backgroundcolor.docString: Sets the background color of this axis' wall.

showaxeslabels.name: boolean
showaxeslabels.docString: Sets whether or not this axis is labeled

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

categoryorder.name: enumerated
categoryorder.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

categoryarray.name: data_array
categoryarray.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

type.name: enumerated
type.docString: Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question.

autotypenumbers.name: enumerated
autotypenumbers.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

autorange.name: enumerated
autorange.docString: Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*.

rangemode.name: enumerated
rangemode.docString: If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes.

range.name: info_array
range.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

nticks.name: integer
nticks.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

tick0.name: any

If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

dtick.name: any

If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

ticktext.name: data_array
ticktext.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: hoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: showline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

args.name: linecolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: linewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

args.name: showgrid
args.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

args.name: gridcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

args.name: gridwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

args.name: zeroline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines.

args.name: zerolinecolor
args.docString: Sets the line color of the zero line.

args.name: zerolinewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

args.name: calendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

args.name: categoryarraysrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

args.name: tickvalssrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

args.name: ticktextsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

visible.name: boolean
visible.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

showspikes.name: boolean
showspikes.docString: Sets whether or not spikes starting from data points to this axis' wall are shown on hover.

spikesides.name: boolean
spikesides.docString: Sets whether or not spikes extending from the projection data points to this axis' wall boundaries are shown on hover.

spikethickness.name: number
spikethickness.docString: Sets the thickness (in px) of the spikes.

spikecolor.name: color
spikecolor.docString: Sets the color of the spikes.

showbackground.name: boolean
showbackground.docString: Sets whether or not this axis' wall has a background color.

backgroundcolor.name: color
backgroundcolor.docString: Sets the background color of this axis' wall.

showaxeslabels.name: boolean
showaxeslabels.docString: Sets whether or not this axis is labeled

color.name: color
color.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

categoryorder.name: enumerated
categoryorder.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

categoryarray.name: data_array
categoryarray.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

type.name: enumerated
type.docString: Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question.

autotypenumbers.name: enumerated
autotypenumbers.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

autorange.name: enumerated
autorange.docString: Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*.

rangemode.name: enumerated
rangemode.docString: If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes.

range.name: info_array
range.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

tickmode.name: enumerated
tickmode.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

nticks.name: integer
nticks.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

tick0.name: any
tick0.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

dtick.name: any
dtick.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

tickvals.name: data_array
tickvals.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

ticktext.name: data_array
ticktext.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

ticks.name: enumerated
ticks.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

mirror.name: enumerated
mirror.docString: Determines if the axis lines or/and ticks are mirrored to the opposite side of the plotting area. If *true*, the axis lines are mirrored. If *ticks*, the axis lines and ticks are mirrored. If *false*, mirroring is disable. If *all*, axis lines are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. If *allticks*, axis lines and ticks are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots.

showticklabels.name: boolean
showticklabels.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

tickangle.name: angle
tickangle.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

showtickprefix.name: enumerated
showtickprefix.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

showticksuffix.name: enumerated
showticksuffix.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

showexponent.name: enumerated
showexponent.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

exponentformat.name: enumerated
exponentformat.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

minexponent.name: number
minexponent.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

tickformat.name: string
tickformat.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

hoverformat.name: string
hoverformat.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

showline.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

linewidth.name: number
linewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

showgrid.name: boolean
showgrid.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

gridcolor.name: color
gridcolor.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

gridwidth.name: number
gridwidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

zeroline.name: boolean
zeroline.docString: Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines.

zerolinecolor.name: color
zerolinecolor.docString: Sets the line color of the zero line.

zerolinewidth.name: number
zerolinewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

calendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

categoryarraysrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

tickvalssrc.name: string
tickvalssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

ticktextsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

range.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

tickmode.name: enumerated
tickmode.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

nticks.name: integer
nticks.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

tick0.name: any
tick0.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

dtick.name: any
dtick.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

tickvals.name: data_array
tickvals.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

ticktext.name: data_array
ticktext.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

ticks.name: enumerated
ticks.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

mirror.name: enumerated
mirror.docString: Determines if the axis lines or/and ticks are mirrored to the opposite side of the plotting area. If *true*, the axis lines are mirrored. If *ticks*, the axis lines and ticks are mirrored. If *false*, mirroring is disable. If *all*, axis lines are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. If *allticks*, axis lines and ticks are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots.

showticklabels.name: boolean
showticklabels.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

tickangle.name: angle
tickangle.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

showtickprefix.name: enumerated
showtickprefix.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

showticksuffix.name: enumerated
showticksuffix.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

showexponent.name: enumerated
showexponent.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

exponentformat.name: enumerated
exponentformat.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

minexponent.name: number
minexponent.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

tickformat.name: string
tickformat.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

hoverformat.name: string
hoverformat.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

showline.name: boolean
showline.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

linewidth.name: number
linewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

showgrid.name: boolean
showgrid.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

gridcolor.name: color
gridcolor.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

gridwidth.name: number
gridwidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

zeroline.name: boolean
zeroline.docString: Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines.

zerolinecolor.name: color
zerolinecolor.docString: Sets the line color of the zero line.

zerolinewidth.name: number
zerolinewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the zero line.

calendar.name: enumerated
calendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

categoryarraysrc.name: string
categoryarraysrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

tickvalssrc.name: string
tickvalssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

ticktextsrc.name: string
ticktextsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this annotation is visible.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the annotation's x position.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the annotation's y position.

args.name: z
args.docString: Sets the annotation's z position.

args.name: ax
args.docString: Sets the x component of the arrow tail about the arrow head (in pixels).

args.name: ay
args.docString: Sets the y component of the arrow tail about the arrow head (in pixels).

args.name: xanchor
args.docString: Sets the text box's horizontal position anchor This anchor binds the `x` position to the *left*, *center* or *right* of the annotation. For example, if `x` is set to 1, `xref` to *paper* and `xanchor` to *right* then the right-most portion of the annotation lines up with the right-most edge of the plotting area. If *auto*, the anchor is equivalent to *center* for data-referenced annotations or if there is an arrow, whereas for paper-referenced with no arrow, the anchor picked corresponds to the closest side.

args.name: xshift
args.docString: Shifts the position of the whole annotation and arrow to the right (positive) or left (negative) by this many pixels.

args.name: yanchor
args.docString: Sets the text box's vertical position anchor This anchor binds the `y` position to the *top*, *middle* or *bottom* of the annotation. For example, if `y` is set to 1, `yref` to *paper* and `yanchor` to *top* then the top-most portion of the annotation lines up with the top-most edge of the plotting area. If *auto*, the anchor is equivalent to *middle* for data-referenced annotations or if there is an arrow, whereas for paper-referenced with no arrow, the anchor picked corresponds to the closest side.

args.name: yshift
args.docString: Shifts the position of the whole annotation and arrow up (positive) or down (negative) by this many pixels.

args.name: text
args.docString:
Sets the text associated with this annotation. Plotly uses a subset of HTML tags to do things like newline (
), bold (), italics (), hyperlinks (). Tags , , are also supported.

args.name: textangle
args.docString: Sets the angle at which the `text` is drawn with respect to the horizontal.

args.name: font
args.docString: Sets the annotation text font.

args.name: width
args.docString:
Sets an explicit width for the text box. null (default) lets the text set the box width. Wider text will be clipped. There is no automatic wrapping; use
to start a new line.

args.name: height
args.docString: Sets an explicit height for the text box. null (default) lets the text set the box height. Taller text will be clipped.

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the annotation (text + arrow).

args.name: align
args.docString:
Sets the horizontal alignment of the `text` within the box. Has an effect only if `text` spans two or more lines (i.e. `text` contains one or more
HTML tags) or if an explicit width is set to override the text width.

args.name: valign
args.docString: Sets the vertical alignment of the `text` within the box. Has an effect only if an explicit height is set to override the text height.

args.name: bgcolor
args.docString: Sets the background color of the annotation.

args.name: bordercolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the border enclosing the annotation `text`.

args.name: borderpad
args.docString: Sets the padding (in px) between the `text` and the enclosing border.

args.name: borderwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the border enclosing the annotation `text`.

args.name: showarrow
args.docString: Determines whether or not the annotation is drawn with an arrow. If *true*, `text` is placed near the arrow's tail. If *false*, `text` lines up with the `x` and `y` provided.

args.name: arrowcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the annotation arrow.

args.name: arrowhead
args.docString: Sets the end annotation arrow head style.

args.name: startarrowhead
args.docString: Sets the start annotation arrow head style.

args.name: arrowside
args.docString: Sets the annotation arrow head position.

args.name: arrowsize
args.docString: Sets the size of the end annotation arrow head, relative to `arrowwidth`. A value of 1 (default) gives a head about 3x as wide as the line.

args.name: startarrowsize
args.docString: Sets the size of the start annotation arrow head, relative to `arrowwidth`. A value of 1 (default) gives a head about 3x as wide as the line.

args.name: arrowwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of annotation arrow line.

args.name: standoff
args.docString: Sets a distance, in pixels, to move the end arrowhead away from the position it is pointing at, for example to point at the edge of a marker independent of zoom. Note that this shortens the arrow from the `ax` / `ay` vector, in contrast to `xshift` / `yshift` which moves everything by this amount.

args.name: startstandoff
args.docString: Sets a distance, in pixels, to move the start arrowhead away from the position it is pointing at, for example to point at the edge of a marker independent of zoom. Note that this shortens the arrow from the `ax` / `ay` vector, in contrast to `xshift` / `yshift` which moves everything by this amount.

args.name: hovertext
args.docString: Sets text to appear when hovering over this annotation. If omitted or blank, no hover label will appear.

args.name: captureevents
args.docString: Determines whether the annotation text box captures mouse move and click events, or allows those events to pass through to data points in the plot that may be behind the annotation. By default `captureevents` is *false* unless `hovertext` is provided. If you use the event `plotly_clickannotation` without `hovertext` you must explicitly enable `captureevents`.

args.name: name
args.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

args.name: templateitemname
args.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

y.name: any

arrowhead.name: integer

arrowside.name: flaglist

arrowsize.name: number

By default `captureevents` is *false* unless `hovertext` is provided. If you use the event `plotly_clickannotation` without `hovertext` you must explicitly enable `captureevents`.

name.name: string
name.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

templateitemname.name: string
templateitemname.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

returns.name: Up
returns.docString: Sets the (x,y,z) components of the 'up' camera vector. This vector determines the up direction of this scene with respect to the page. The default is *{x: 0, y: 0, z: 1}* which means that the z axis points up.

returns.name: Center
returns.docString: Sets the (x,y,z) components of the 'center' camera vector This vector determines the translation (x,y,z) space about the center of this scene. By default, there is no such translation.

returns.name: Eye
returns.docString: Sets the (x,y,z) components of the 'eye' camera vector. This vector determines the view point about the origin of this scene.

args.name: type
args.docString: Sets the projection type. The projection type could be either *perspective* or *orthographic*. The default is *perspective*.

type.name: enumerated
type.docString: Sets the projection type. The projection type could be either *perspective* or *orthographic*. The default is *perspective*.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the title of this axis. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated.

args.name: font
args.docString: Sets this axis' title font. Note that the title's font used to be customized by the now deprecated `titlefont` attribute.

text.name: string
text.docString: Sets the title of this axis. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated.

args.name: family
args.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.name: Tickfont

These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.name: Tickfont

args.name: enabled
args.docString: Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`.

args.name: dtickrange
args.docString: range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null*

args.name: value
args.docString: string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat*

args.name: name
args.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

args.name: templateitemname
args.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the horizontal domain of this geo subplot (in plot fraction). Note that geo subplots are constrained by domain. In general, when `projection.scale` is set to 1. a map will fit either its x or y domain, but not both.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the vertical domain of this geo subplot (in plot fraction). Note that geo subplots are constrained by domain. In general, when `projection.scale` is set to 1. a map will fit either its x or y domain, but not both.

args.name: row
args.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this row in the grid for this geo subplot . Note that geo subplots are constrained by domain. In general, when `projection.scale` is set to 1. a map will fit either its x or y domain, but not both.

args.name: column
args.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this column in the grid for this geo subplot . Note that geo subplots are constrained by domain. In general, when `projection.scale` is set to 1. a map will fit either its x or y domain, but not both.

y.name: info_array

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether this layer is displayed

args.name: sourcetype
args.docString: Sets the source type for this layer, that is the type of the layer data.

args.name: source
args.docString: Sets the source data for this layer (mapbox.layer.source). When `sourcetype` is set to *geojson*, `source` can be a URL to a GeoJSON or a GeoJSON object. When `sourcetype` is set to *vector* or *raster*, `source` can be a URL or an array of tile URLs. When `sourcetype` is set to *image*, `source` can be a URL to an image.

args.name: sourcelayer
args.docString: Specifies the layer to use from a vector tile source (mapbox.layer.source-layer). Required for *vector* source type that supports multiple layers.

args.name: sourceattribution
args.docString: Sets the attribution for this source.

args.name: type
args.docString: Sets the layer type, that is the how the layer data set in `source` will be rendered With `sourcetype` set to *geojson*, the following values are allowed: *circle*, *line*, *fill* and *symbol*. but note that *line* and *fill* are not compatible with Point GeoJSON geometries. With `sourcetype` set to *vector*, the following values are allowed:  *circle*, *line*, *fill* and *symbol*. With `sourcetype` set to *raster* or `*image*`, only the *raster* value is allowed.

args.name: coordinates
args.docString: Sets the coordinates array contains [longitude, latitude] pairs for the image corners listed in clockwise order: top left, top right, bottom right, bottom left. Only has an effect for *image* `sourcetype`.

args.name: below
args.docString: Determines if the layer will be inserted before the layer with the specified ID. If omitted or set to '', the layer will be inserted above every existing layer.

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets the primary layer color. If `type` is *circle*, color corresponds to the circle color (mapbox.layer.paint.circle-color) If `type` is *line*, color corresponds to the line color (mapbox.layer.paint.line-color) If `type` is *fill*, color corresponds to the fill color (mapbox.layer.paint.fill-color) If `type` is *symbol*, color corresponds to the icon color (mapbox.layer.paint.icon-color)

args.name: opacity
args.docString: Sets the opacity of the layer. If `type` is *circle*, opacity corresponds to the circle opacity (mapbox.layer.paint.circle-opacity) If `type` is *line*, opacity corresponds to the line opacity (mapbox.layer.paint.line-opacity) If `type` is *fill*, opacity corresponds to the fill opacity (mapbox.layer.paint.fill-opacity) If `type` is *symbol*, opacity corresponds to the icon/text opacity (mapbox.layer.paint.text-opacity)

args.name: minzoom
args.docString: Sets the minimum zoom level (mapbox.layer.minzoom). At zoom levels less than the minzoom, the layer will be hidden.

args.name: maxzoom
args.docString: Sets the maximum zoom level (mapbox.layer.maxzoom). At zoom levels equal to or greater than the maxzoom, the layer will be hidden.

args.name: name
args.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

args.name: templateitemname
args.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

If `type` is *circle*, color corresponds to the circle color (mapbox.layer.paint.circle-color) If `type` is *line*, color corresponds to the line color (mapbox.layer.paint.line-color) If `type` is *fill*, color corresponds to the fill color (mapbox.layer.paint.fill-color) If `type` is *symbol*, color corresponds to the icon color (mapbox.layer.paint.icon-color)

opacity.name: number
opacity.docString: Sets the opacity of the layer. If `type` is *circle*, opacity corresponds to the circle opacity (mapbox.layer.paint.circle-opacity) If `type` is *line*, opacity corresponds to the line opacity (mapbox.layer.paint.line-opacity) If `type` is *fill*, opacity corresponds to the fill opacity (mapbox.layer.paint.fill-opacity) If `type` is *symbol*, opacity corresponds to the icon/text opacity (mapbox.layer.paint.text-opacity)

minzoom.name: number
minzoom.docString: Sets the minimum zoom level (mapbox.layer.minzoom). At zoom levels less than the minzoom, the layer will be hidden.

maxzoom.name: number
maxzoom.docString: Sets the maximum zoom level (mapbox.layer.maxzoom). At zoom levels equal to or greater than the maxzoom, the layer will be hidden.

name.name: string
name.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

templateitemname.name: string
templateitemname.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

args.name: radius
args.docString: Sets the circle radius (mapbox.layer.paint.circle-radius). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *circle*.

radius.name: number
radius.docString: Sets the circle radius (mapbox.layer.paint.circle-radius). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *circle*.

args.name: width
args.docString: Sets the line width (mapbox.layer.paint.line-width). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *line*.

args.name: dash
args.docString: Sets the length of dashes and gaps (mapbox.layer.paint.line-dasharray). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *line*.

args.name: dashsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  dash .

width.name: number
width.docString: Sets the line width (mapbox.layer.paint.line-width). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *line*.

dash.name: data_array
dash.docString: Sets the length of dashes and gaps (mapbox.layer.paint.line-dasharray). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *line*.

dashsrc.name: string
dashsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  dash .

args.name: outlinecolor
args.docString: Sets the fill outline color (mapbox.layer.paint.fill-outline-color). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *fill*.

outlinecolor.name: color
outlinecolor.docString: Sets the fill outline color (mapbox.layer.paint.fill-outline-color). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *fill*.

args.name: icon
args.docString: Sets the symbol icon image (mapbox.layer.layout.icon-image). Full list: https://www.mapbox.com/maki-icons/

args.name: iconsize
args.docString: Sets the symbol icon size (mapbox.layer.layout.icon-size). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *symbol*.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the symbol text (mapbox.layer.layout.text-field).

args.name: placement
args.docString: Sets the symbol and/or text placement (mapbox.layer.layout.symbol-placement). If `placement` is *point*, the label is placed where the geometry is located If `placement` is *line*, the label is placed along the line of the geometry If `placement` is *line-center*, the label is placed on the center of the geometry

args.name: textfont
args.docString: Sets the icon text font (color=mapbox.layer.paint.text-color, size=mapbox.layer.layout.text-size). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *symbol*.

args.name: textposition
args.docString: Sets the positions of the `text` elements with respects to the (x,y) coordinates.

icon.docString: Sets the symbol icon image (mapbox.layer.layout.icon-image). Full list: https://www.mapbox.com/maki-icons/

iconsize.name: number
