textposition.name: enumerated
textposition.docString: Sets the positions of the `text` elements with respects to the (x,y) coordinates.

args.name: family
args.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.name: Textfont

family.name: string
family.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.docString: Sets the icon text font (color=mapbox.layer.paint.text-color, size=mapbox.layer.layout.text-size). Has an effect only when `type` is set to *symbol*.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the horizontal domain of this polar subplot (in plot fraction).

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the vertical domain of this polar subplot (in plot fraction).

args.name: row
args.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this row in the grid for this polar subplot .

args.name: column
args.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this column in the grid for this polar subplot .

x.name: info_array
x.docString: Sets the horizontal domain of this polar subplot (in plot fraction).

y.name: info_array
y.docString: Sets the vertical domain of this polar subplot (in plot fraction).

row.name: integer
row.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this row in the grid for this polar subplot .

column.name: integer
column.docString: If there is a layout grid, use the domain for this column in the grid for this polar subplot .

args.name: visible
args.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

args.name: type
args.docString: Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question.

args.name: autotypenumbers
args.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

args.name: autorange
args.docString: Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*.

args.name: rangemode
args.docString: If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data (same behavior as for cartesian axes).

args.name: range
args.docString: Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: categoryorder
args.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

args.name: categoryarray
args.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

args.name: angle
args.docString: Sets the angle (in degrees) from which the radial axis is drawn. Note that by default, radial axis line on the theta=0 line corresponds to a line pointing right (like what mathematicians prefer). Defaults to the first `polar.sector` angle.

args.name: side
args.docString: Determines on which side of radial axis line the tick and tick labels appear.

args.name: hoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `range`, `autorange`, `angle`, and `title` if in `editable: true` configuration. Defaults to `polar<N>.uirevision`.

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

args.name: showline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

args.name: linecolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: linewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

args.name: showgrid
args.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

args.name: gridcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

args.name: gridwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

args.name: tickmode
args.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

args.name: nticks
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

args.name: tick0
args.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: dtick
args.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

args.name: tickvals
args.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

args.name: ticktext
args.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

args.name: ticks
args.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

args.name: ticklen
args.docString: Sets the tick length (in px).

args.name: tickwidth
args.docString: Sets the tick width (in px).

args.name: tickcolor
args.docString: Sets the tick color.

args.name: showticklabels
args.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

args.name: showtickprefix
args.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

args.name: tickprefix
args.docString: Sets a tick label prefix.

args.name: showticksuffix
args.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

args.name: ticksuffix
args.docString: Sets a tick label suffix.

args.name: showexponent
args.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

args.name: exponentformat
args.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

args.name: minexponent
args.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

args.name: separatethousands
args.docString: If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated

args.name: tickfont
args.docString: Sets the tick font.

args.name: tickangle
args.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

args.name: tickformat
args.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: layer
args.docString: Sets the layer on which this axis is displayed. If *above traces*, this axis is displayed above all the subplot's traces If *below traces*, this axis is displayed below all the subplot's traces, but above the grid lines. Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis.

args.name: calendar
args.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

args.name: categoryarraysrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

args.name: tickvalssrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

args.name: ticktextsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

layer.name: enumerated
layer.docString: Sets the layer on which this axis is displayed. If *above traces*, this axis is displayed above all the subplot's traces If *below traces*, this axis is displayed below all the subplot's traces, but above the grid lines. Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis.

calendar.name: enumerated
calendar.docString: Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar`

categoryarraysrc.name: string
categoryarraysrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  categoryarray .

tickvalssrc.name: string
tickvalssrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

ticktextsrc.name: string
ticktextsrc.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

args.name: visible
args.docString: A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false

args.name: type
args.docString: Sets the angular axis type. If *linear*, set `thetaunit` to determine the unit in which axis value are shown. If *category, use `period` to set the number of integer coordinates around polar axis.

args.name: autotypenumbers
args.docString: Using *strict* a numeric string in trace data is not converted to a number. Using *convert types* a numeric string in trace data may be treated as a number during automatic axis `type` detection. Defaults to layout.autotypenumbers.

args.name: categoryorder
args.docString: Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. Set `categoryorder` to *total ascending* or *total descending* if order should be determined by the numerical order of the values. Similarly, the order can be determined by the min, max, sum, mean or median of all the values.

args.name: categoryarray
args.docString: Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`.

args.name: thetaunit
args.docString: Sets the format unit of the formatted *theta* values. Has an effect only when `angularaxis.type` is *linear*.

args.name: period
args.docString: Set the angular period. Has an effect only when `angularaxis.type` is *category*.

args.name: direction
args.docString: Sets the direction corresponding to positive angles.

args.name: rotation
args.docString: Sets that start position (in degrees) of the angular axis By default, polar subplots with `direction` set to *counterclockwise* get a `rotation` of *0* which corresponds to due East (like what mathematicians prefer). In turn, polar with `direction` set to *clockwise* get a rotation of *90* which corresponds to due North (like on a compass),

args.name: hoverformat
args.docString: Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: uirevision
args.docString: Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `rotation`. Defaults to `polar<N>.uirevision`.

args.name: color
args.docString: Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this.

args.name: showline
args.docString: Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn.

args.name: linecolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: linewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

args.name: showgrid
args.docString: Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark.

args.name: gridcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of the grid lines.

args.name: gridwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines.

args.name: tickmode
args.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

args.name: nticks
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

args.name: tick0
args.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: dtick
args.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

args.name: tickvals
args.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

args.name: ticktext
args.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

args.name: ticks
args.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

args.name: ticklen
args.docString: Sets the tick length (in px).

args.name: tickwidth
args.docString: Sets the tick width (in px).

args.name: tickcolor
args.docString: Sets the tick color.

args.name: showticklabels
args.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

args.name: showtickprefix
args.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

args.name: tickprefix
args.docString: Sets a tick label prefix.

args.name: showticksuffix
args.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

args.name: ticksuffix
args.docString: Sets a tick label suffix.

args.name: showexponent
args.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

args.name: exponentformat
args.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

args.name: minexponent
args.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

args.name: separatethousands
args.docString: If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated

args.name: tickfont
args.docString: Sets the tick font.

args.name: tickangle
args.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

args.name: tickformat
args.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the title of this axis. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated.

args.name: font
args.docString: Sets this axis' title font. Note that the title's font used to be customized by the now deprecated `titlefont` attribute.

text.name: string
text.docString: Sets the title of this axis. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated.

args.name: family
args.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.name: Tickfont

Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.docString: Sets the tick font.

args.name: enabled
args.docString: Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`.

args.name: dtickrange
args.docString: range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null*

args.name: value
args.docString: string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat*

args.name: name
args.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

args.name: templateitemname
args.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

enabled.name: boolean
enabled.docString: Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`.

dtickrange.name: info_array
dtickrange.docString: range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null*

value.name: string
value.docString: string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat*

If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

args.name: templateitemname
args.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

enabled.name: boolean
enabled.docString: Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`.

dtickrange.name: info_array
dtickrange.docString: range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null*

value.name: string
value.docString: string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat*

name.name: string
name.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

templateitemname.name: string
templateitemname.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

args.name: family
args.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.name: Font

returns.docString: Sets the font used to text the legend items.

args.name: bgcolor
args.docString: Sets the background color of the hover label. By default uses the annotation's `bgcolor` made opaque, or white if it was transparent.

args.name: bordercolor
args.docString: Sets the border color of the hover label. By default uses either dark grey or white, for maximum contrast with `hoverlabel.bgcolor`.

args.name: visible
args.docString: Determines whether or not this button is visible.

args.name: method
args.docString: Sets the Plotly method to be called on click. If the `skip` method is used, the API updatemenu will function as normal but will perform no API calls and will not bind automatically to state updates. This may be used to create a component interface and attach to updatemenu events manually via JavaScript.

args.name: args
args.docString: Sets the arguments values to be passed to the Plotly method set in `method` on click.

args.name: args2
args.docString: Sets a 2nd set of `args`, these arguments values are passed to the Plotly method set in `method` when clicking this button while in the active state. Use this to create toggle buttons.

args.name: label
args.docString: Sets the text label to appear on the button.

args.name: execute
args.docString: When true, the API method is executed. When false, all other behaviors are the same and command execution is skipped. This may be useful when hooking into, for example, the `plotly_buttonclicked` method and executing the API command manually without losing the benefit of the updatemenu automatically binding to the state of the plot through the specification of `method` and `args`.

args.name: thicknessmode
args.docString: Determines whether this color bar's thickness (i.e. the measure in the constant color direction) is set in units of plot *fraction* or in *pixels*. Use `thickness` to set the value.

args.name: thickness
args.docString: Sets the thickness of the color bar This measure excludes the size of the padding, ticks and labels.

args.name: lenmode
args.docString: Determines whether this color bar's length (i.e. the measure in the color variation direction) is set in units of plot *fraction* or in *pixels. Use `len` to set the value.

args.name: len
args.docString: Sets the length of the color bar This measure excludes the padding of both ends. That is, the color bar length is this length minus the padding on both ends.

args.name: x
args.docString: Sets the x position of the color bar (in plot fraction).

args.name: xanchor
args.docString: Sets this color bar's horizontal position anchor. This anchor binds the `x` position to the *left*, *center* or *right* of the color bar.

args.name: xpad
args.docString: Sets the amount of padding (in px) along the x direction.

args.name: y
args.docString: Sets the y position of the color bar (in plot fraction).

args.name: yanchor
args.docString: Sets this color bar's vertical position anchor This anchor binds the `y` position to the *top*, *middle* or *bottom* of the color bar.

args.name: ypad
args.docString: Sets the amount of padding (in px) along the y direction.

args.name: outlinecolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: outlinewidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

args.name: bordercolor
args.docString: Sets the axis line color.

args.name: borderwidth
args.docString: Sets the width (in px) or the border enclosing this color bar.

args.name: bgcolor
args.docString: Sets the color of padded area.

args.name: tickmode
args.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

args.name: nticks
args.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

args.name: tick0
args.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

args.name: dtick
args.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

args.name: tickvals
args.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

args.name: ticktext
args.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

args.name: ticks
args.docString: Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines.

args.name: ticklabelposition
args.docString: Determines where tick labels are drawn.

args.name: ticklen
args.docString: Sets the tick length (in px).

args.name: tickwidth
args.docString: Sets the tick width (in px).

args.name: tickcolor
args.docString: Sets the tick color.

args.name: showticklabels
args.docString: Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn.

args.name: tickfont
args.docString: Sets the color bar's tick label font

args.name: tickangle
args.docString: Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically.

args.name: tickformat
args.docString: Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46*

args.name: tickprefix
args.docString: Sets a tick label prefix.

args.name: showtickprefix
args.docString: If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden.

args.name: ticksuffix
args.docString: Sets a tick label suffix.

args.name: showticksuffix
args.docString: Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes.

args.name: separatethousands
args.docString: If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated

args.name: exponentformat
args.docString: Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B.

args.name: minexponent
args.docString: Hide SI prefix for 10^n if |n| is below this number. This only has an effect when `tickformat` is *SI* or *B*.

args.name: showexponent
args.docString: If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear.

args.name: tickvalssrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  tickvals .

args.name: ticktextsrc
args.docString: Sets the source reference on Chart Studio Cloud for  ticktext .

thicknessmode.name: enumerated
thicknessmode.docString: Determines whether this color bar's thickness (i.e. the measure in the constant color direction) is set in units of plot *fraction* or in *pixels*. Use `thickness` to set the value.

thickness.name: number
thickness.docString: Sets the thickness of the color bar This measure excludes the size of the padding, ticks and labels.

lenmode.name: enumerated
lenmode.docString: Determines whether this color bar's length (i.e. the measure in the color variation direction) is set in units of plot *fraction* or in *pixels. Use `len` to set the value.

len.name: number
len.docString: Sets the length of the color bar This measure excludes the padding of both ends. That is, the color bar length is this length minus the padding on both ends.

x.name: number
x.docString: Sets the x position of the color bar (in plot fraction).

xanchor.name: enumerated
xanchor.docString: Sets this color bar's horizontal position anchor. This anchor binds the `x` position to the *left*, *center* or *right* of the color bar.

xpad.name: number
xpad.docString: Sets the amount of padding (in px) along the x direction.

y.name: number
y.docString: Sets the y position of the color bar (in plot fraction).

yanchor.name: enumerated
yanchor.docString: Sets this color bar's vertical position anchor This anchor binds the `y` position to the *top*, *middle* or *bottom* of the color bar.

ypad.name: number
ypad.docString: Sets the amount of padding (in px) along the y direction.

outlinewidth.name: number
outlinewidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) of the axis line.

bordercolor.name: color
bordercolor.docString: Sets the axis line color.

borderwidth.name: number
borderwidth.docString: Sets the width (in px) or the border enclosing this color bar.

bgcolor.name: color
bgcolor.docString: Sets the color of padded area.

tickmode.name: enumerated
tickmode.docString: Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided).

nticks.name: integer
nticks.docString: Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*.

tick0.name: any
tick0.docString: Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears.

dtick.name: any
dtick.docString: Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48*

tickvals.name: data_array
tickvals.docString: Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`.

ticktext.name: data_array
ticktext.docString: Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`.

For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-3.x-api-reference/blob/master/Formatting.md#d3_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. args.name: family
args.docString: HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The Chart Studio Cloud (at https://chart-studio.plotly.com or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*.

returns.name: Tickfont

returns.docString: Sets the color bar's tick label font

args.name: enabled
args.docString: Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`.

args.name: dtickrange
args.docString: range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null*

args.name: value
args.docString: string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat*

args.name: name
args.docString: When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

args.name: templateitemname
args.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

enabled.name: boolean
enabled.docString: Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`.

dtickrange.name: info_array
dtickrange.docString: range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null*

value.name: string
value.docString: string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat*

name.name: string

You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template.

templateitemname.name: string
templateitemname.docString: Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`.

args.name: text
args.docString: Sets the title of the color bar. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated.

args.name: font
args.docString: Sets this color bar's title font. Note that the title's font used to be set by the now deprecated `titlefont` attribute.

args.name: side
args.docString: Determines the location of color bar's title with respect to the color bar. Note that the title's location used to be set by the now deprecated `titleside` attribute.

side.name: enumerated

returns.name: Font
